item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: About Mark Allen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Mark Allen is arguably the most successful triathlete in the history of the sport. He was the first ever ITU Olympic Distance World Champion in 1989 in Avignon France, the 6-Time Hawaii Ironman World Champion and the 10-Time Undefeated Champion of the Nice International Triathlon to name a few of his historic racing accomplishments. In 2012 he was voted "The Greatest Endurance Athlete of All Time" in a worldwide poll conducted by ESPN.

Perhaps the most interesting aspect of his 15-year career as a world-class triathlete is that Mark never had a coach! He had to figure out how to be the best in the world on his own through trial and error by scouring sports research periodicals looking for the most effective training methods, nutritional advice and injury prevention technics, and then putting the best information available to the ultimate test by training over 15,000 miles each and every year of his career.

What Mark found was that some tools that science said were essential to the success of an athlete were indeed effective. However, he discovered the hard way that most of what research claimed was key to racing at your best just fell short when applied in the real world of day to day training, and especially when he tried to employ those methods personally to help him get ready for just a handful of key races each and every year. Tim Noakes, who is perhaps the most acclaimed researcher in the world of endurance athletics, once said about Mark that there is a gap between what science knows and what happens in the real world, and this man has proven it without a doubt!

Mark made the mistakes. He learned from them. He refined what worked. Then over time he developed the most effective training protocol of any athlete in the sport! He has helped aspiring triathletes complete their first ever triathlon as well as worked with professionals to and guided them to become World Champions.

Mark is sharing this wealth of direct knowledge and effective training methods with you through MarkAllenCoaching. Now through the guidance of Mark and a small group of hand picked coaching experts, you can access the brain of a champion directly through MarkAllenCoaching!

Get ready for the racing experience of a lifetime with MarkAllenCoaching!

item.title: Our Partners
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Lumo Bodytech's technology platform leverages smart sensors and software to optimize performance and address human biomechanics through the real-time tracking of body movement.

Salming Sports is a Swedish sporting goods company established in 2008, with US headquarters in North Carolina. They offer a range of proven race, road, and trail shoes and were selected as Best Shoe Debut for 2014 by Runner’s World.

ROKA is a performance triathlon brand that was started by two former Stanford swimmers that produces top, race-winning triathlon wetsuits, swimskins, SIM shorts and other training and racing apparel and equipment.

Garmin produces the most innovative GPS products for multisport athletes. With a full line of Ant+ and Bluetooth enabled wrist and bike-mount computers there’s a GPS device for every cyclist, runner and triathlete.

ENVE has gained a reputation as a leader in composite wheel design and manufacturing, ENVE partnered with renowned aerodynamicist Simon Smart (Smart Aero Technologies) to develop a unique aero wheel product that specifically met the needs of triathletes and time trialists of all levels and disciplines. The result is a complete wheel line known as the Smart ENVE System.

KiWAMi produces first-class triathlon race-wear that is specifically designed and tailored to enhance the performance of the competitor. KiWAMi uses only top quality fabrics that are adapted for the triathlon; supportive, streamlined and water repellent for swimming; fast drying, body-hugging and comfortable for cycling; lightweight, breathable and flexible for running.

 

TriSports.com is the world's leading triathlon retail store. Many of the staff are triathletes - living and breathing the multisport lifestyle while providing excellent customer service and an extensive product selection of triathlon wetsuits, aero race wheels, tri bikes, road bikes, triathlon clothing, running shoes - everything - to triathletes around the globe. They are dedicated not only to the sport, but also to their customers, their employees and the environment.

item.title: Get Started
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As a current or aspiring triathlete you may ask yourself “how can I get the best out of my training time and maximize my potential?” Since 1994 Mark has been helping athletes with training plans that answer those two critical questions. With any program you sign up for through MarkAllenCoaching you will not only receive what he feels is the best possible training available anywhere, but also the highest quality support from a small staff of select top level coaches. Everyone at MarkAllenCoaching is dedicated to making your triathlon journey and your experience in the sport the best you can possibly have.   All training plans are developed through MarkAllenCoaching and delivered both via the web and your mobile devices. We are currently working on a great feature where you will be able to upload all your data from Garmin and have a log of your workout history and specific training data stored online for easy analysis and as your personal resource should you ever want to go back over your training history in the future.   With each package you receive a three phase training program that takes you through base building, then onto speedwork and eventually to the all-important taper down to your key races. Intensity levels are set by heart rate to help you maximize the physiological benefits of each and every session. Real core gains in fitness can then be measured by using Garmin or any other GPS device to track your fitness gains in your power output by tracking watts while cycling and pace while running against these heart rates.   You will also receive a four-phase strength-training program that is essential for boosting the benefits of your swim, bike and run workouts. There are two options. One is a traditional strength program and the other that will also come online for 2015 will be a functional strength alternative designed specifically for triathletes and their needs for core stability along with muscular gains in raw power.   Included with all programs is unlimited email support for any questions you have or feedback you desire. You will also be able to access a new tool for gaining information about the sport at the Tri-FAQ knowledge base. It is filled with great information about training, racing, nutrition, equipment and mindset.   Every training plan is tailored to the race distance you are going to target in your main season. This includes everything from sprint distance all the way to full-length triathlons. With the customized approach your current fitness and past training history is taken into consideration and incorporated into the creation of your training plans making MarkAllenCoaching ideal for triathletes of all levels of ability from the first timers all the way up to seasons veterans in the sport.     Types of Training Programs   MarkAllenCoaching offers two types of training plans:

Premium Coaching Package: This is a fully customized program designed specifically to get you ready to race. The workouts are built around the days of the week that you want to do your workouts and the number of workouts in each sport that you prefer. Included with your day-to-day training the premium coaching package includes unlimited email support from our coaching staff to help guide you through your training and answer any questions you have, and to provide feedback on your progress when you have questions about that as well. The length of these programs are up to any length up to 20-weeks.

Off Season Coaching Package: The focus with these training sessions is to allow for full recovery after your racing season is done, or at any point during the season when a reduction in overall training volume and intensity is needed. These programs deliver daily training that is designed around helping you maintain enough of a base of fitness to be able to seamlessly transition back into the racing plans as you start to get within at least 20-weeks to your next goal race. Overall volume is less than in the Premium racing schedules and there are just enough faster anaerobic sessions to help keep your body activated while still affording the deeper recovery necessary in the off season. You get all features of the day-to-day training and get unlimited email support as well as to access the Tri-FAQ knowledge base as a resource to help understand the philosophies necessary to maximize your workouts and racing.

  Pricing: The cost of training plans depends on how many weeks you want to purchase at a time. The Premium programs require a 3-week initial purchase and the Off Season package requires a 2-week initial purchase. You will be able to see as many weeks as you have paid for on your schedule.   Pay Weekly - the cost is $35/week if you purchase training on a weekly basis. Pay for 6-12 Weeks - the cost is $30/week if you purchase a block of 6-12 weeks of training at one time. Pay for 13-20 Weeks - the cost is $25/week if you purchase a block of 13-20 weeks all at once.

Pay for a Year Membership - the cost for 52-weeks of coaching is $20/week and can start anytime you wish. Your weekly credits never expire!

item.title: BELIEF
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This one word carries weight. It holds force and potential. It can tip the scales away from failure and place success directly in your sites. Belief is made up of trust and hope and commitment and surrender. It connects action with possibility and dreams with reality. Belief buoys you up when the road ahead looks hopeless. It helps you take the next step when your lesser self would listen to that silent voice blaring out to ears only you can hear telling you it’s just not worth it to go on. It’s a friend, a trusted ally that unites all your efforts and energies into a charge that can achieve magnificence. It’s athletic rocket fuel. But as potent of an influence as belief can be in a race as demanding as the Ironman, you cannot just go to the corner market and pick some up. Belief is intangible. You feel it when you have it; you know when you lose it. It has mass and yields significance because it is the sum total of every experience you have had in life leading up to the exact moment in time when suddenly the final piece comes to you and there is a knowing inside that now you have what it takes. Rock solid knowing. Unwavering knowing. Unbounded enthusiastic knowing. Deep silent peaceful knowing. Three hundred and sixty-four days before the 2013 Hawaii Ironman World Championships I was talking with a guy who had just finished third the day before in Kona. Impressive without a doubt! But was it enough to give him that elusive belief necessary to know inside that he had what it took to be the champion? Rock solid belief? We spoke about things like race strategy and training and mindset; post race Ironman stuff. I’m still not sure which piece of the conversation it was, and I have no idea if it was something I said or just a solution that he arrived at on his own, but something happened on that lanai next to Kailua Bay where Cervelo was acknowledging all their top athletes. I could see it in his eyes, hear it in his voice. The final nugget needed to carry Frederik Van Lierde to critical mass locked in and turned on belief. Deep silent peaceful belief. One year later Van Lierde would up his game to very significant places and outpace the rest of the world on a day in the men’s race where tactics turned relatively mild Ironman conditions into an extremely challenging race to win. Belief is not uniform. There’s the little belief, the one that says I know I can do it if things go my way, if my game is on, if I can believe in myself when it gets tough and stick to my strategy when my competitors are trying to pull me off it. But the big BELIEF has no caveats. It takes every “if” out of the equation and allows you to embrace all roads ahead, especially the ones that are lined with uncertainty, with challenges that look insurmountable, the roads that have no guidebook telling you how to navigate them. The big BELIEF helps you put your arms around the enormity race reality can have and allows you to dismantle every challenge the day brings, piece by painstaking piece, until there is nothing left separating you from greatness. For Mirinda Carfrae the big BELIEF has always been in her court, in her core makeup. It just took more than one race to rediscover her way to Ali’i Drive’s hallowed finishing chute before all other challengers. You see, even if we are unwavering in our commitment, in our knowing of what lies inside, it can take a confidant (or two) with equal belief in us to help unleash it. In 2010 Carfrae let greatness reign by not only winning the Ironman World Championship, but by breaking her previous marathon record with a time of 2:53:32. The big BELIEF. But the next year she finished second to the one woman who seemed to be walking on water when it came to Ironman racing: Chrissie Wellington. Carfrae set a marathon mark for her third time of 2:52:09 in that 2011 race, but came in just under three minutes shy of a repeat victory. Critics were putting the silent asterisks next to her previous win. “Would she have won if Chrissie had been there in 2010” were the unspoken words. Mirinda didn’t bat an eye. The next year in 2012 her result seemed even further from her “A” game. Third place, and not even within striking range of a new run record. But it took her one step closer to a performance that will stand out as one of the greatest ever in Ironman history. Greatness always has its own pace, its own timeline, and it’s up to us if we are going to hang in there long enough for it to play out in our lives, or if we are just going to call it a day because we lack the patience to fully embrace the bigger plan. Carfrae took option A. This year she returned to the guidance of her 2010 coach, Siri Lindley who is “BELIEF” written in something even bigger than capital letters. Critical mass had been reached. Time for launch. With belief times ten, Carfrae not only broke Wellington’s course record and in the process put a gag order on anyone who might have doubted her ability to outpace Chrissie on her best day, and she did it in astounding style. Here it is again: new course record of 8:52:14; new marathon record of 2:50:38; third fastest run of the day, man or woman; out-split the men’s champ by 40 seconds on the marathon. I know you have likely read all of those stats, but no recounting of this year’s Ironman would be complete without them. Belief. Rock solid belief! Belief is something more than saying I can win. It’s knowing with every cell in your body that you are willing to lock in, engage and commit regardless of how clearly you see your dreams or how out of reach they may appear in the toughest parts of the journey. Real belief will take that risk anyway because you grasp how stupendous really giving it your all is, and that even if come up short your life will be better for trying. Ironman Hawaii is built on uncertainty. That is what makes it great. The day starts with a big but very vague sense of what the journey is really going to take to complete. Even if you have done it many times before, the task ahead from cannon shot to finish line is revealed one swim stroke, one pedal stroke at a time. What you have gotten yourself into slowly comes into focus as the hours wear on. The energy of the day compresses in closer and tighter with each step you take on the marathon. It’s like you are being shrink-wrapped by reality. And there always comes a moment, a very defining moment, when the thousand other big challenges that have come before pale in comparison to the one you are standing face to face with, the biggest one you will need to confront in your quest for greatness. You can’t look left for solace. You can’t look right for relief. You must look directly ahead, inside, and find belief in yourself, belief in the Big Island and that it is helping your race unfold exactly as it should. The Big Belief. It sits in the same room as fear, as self-doubt and cynicism. But if you look deep enough, long enough you will see that your belief in yourself has its back turned away from these corrosive qualities. It’s looking the opposite direction staring openly at possibility, and trust. It’s showing you the reason you will take the next step and why it’s worth it. Harriet Anderson may have been faced with that moment at mile 95 of the bike when she hit a rock and went sailing into the railing just to the side of the road. The railing did its job and saved her from an even more disastrous outcome. But even with bruises, a few cuts and a broken right aero bar she found the reasons to continue. She became the final women’s finisher and oldest for the day. Her finish time with the crash as a 77-year-old was an amazing 16:56:51. Harriet, you give us all belief in doing the impossible. The Big Belief!

item.title: BIG RACE MINDSET
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: When the gun goes off to the biggest race of the season, all speculation stops. How you and your training partners will do is going to play out regardless of what was said prior to the event. No more training can be done. Nothing can be added or taken away from how you have prepared. The money’s in the bank and it’s time to make the final withdrawal of the season. The challenge can be to translate all that stored up fitness into the race you are hoping for. Here are few tips to help you find a mindset that will allow you to do that. Pacing- This may sound like a physical issue. You can go too easy, too fast, or just right. Finding the ‘Just Right’ is actually a mental game. It requires the endless computations that your brain must make by taking in all the signals your body is telling you about whether you are maximizing a pace that is sustainable, assess the pain signals telling you to slow down that inherently present themselves to in a race, then figure out if you are actually going as fast as you can without burning all your matches too early. It’s complicated! And there are a million ways to get from the start to the finish. But the one that is going to be best for you will come when you can forget that there is going to be some kind of outcome from crossing the finish line and just immerse yourself in the moment to moment rhythm of your body covers time and space at its peak capacity. This is a call to not worry about whether you are having a great race or a lousy one, and certainly as best as possible suspend any assessment of the result of the race you are having. In other words, maybe you are afraid you won’t achieve a goal you had set for yourself, or you are already tossing in the towel to a competitor of yours who is starting to pull away and its giving you a feeling like you will never succeed. No matter what the scenario playing out in your mind (especially if it’s a negative one) just shut off the internal chatter and race. Pretty simple! Find your personal place of quiet inside. Stop trying to have a great race, and take the next step that fully immerses you in doing just that. Take the pain as a byproduct of peak performance and of you getting the best out of your body. It’s all part of the day. If you had wanted something different, you would have come as a spectator! Gratitude- If you are finding your mindset is taking a dive at any point in the race try to just ride it out. There is never a race where a person feels fantastic the entire way, especially if it is a long event like Ironman. There will more than likely be a thousand points where you want to give up, back off or even quit. This is just part of the experience. Remind yourself that it is okay to have a lousy attitude, that you don’t have to feel outstanding and be ecstatic the entire day to be having the best race of your life. But as best as possible, try to not dwell in that place. Ride it out and let it pass. Keep going at least until you find a more positive focus come back. Wait until you get in that space that just says, “Okay this is how it is right now. What do I need to do to take the next step, to get to the next aid station, to relax my muscles just a bit and find my rhythm once again?” If all else fails, take a look around at where you are. You will likely be in an incredibly beautiful place. Yes, even the stark lava of The Big Island of Hawaii is a paradise if looked at through the right lenses. Forget that you are not feeling super at that moment and remember how lucky you are that you are still out there racing, doing something that most of humanity would not even consider doing. You are in rarified air, and the challenge of the moment is just the small price of the ride. Gratitude can switch everything. Quiet- When all else fails, search out that quiet place inside, the point in your personality and makeup that can never be negatively affected by a bad patch in an otherwise incredible day. In that place of quiet you might get the answer of how to keep going, and see the day in the big perspective of your life. It may take a few moments to calm the chatter, but it will come. And when it does, you’ll be free. You’ll remember some key workouts you did getting ready for the race that had moments that were tougher than this but that you made it through and you’ll gain strength from that memory. You’ll have access to the full amount of fitness that you have stored up getting ready for the biggest race of your season and it will be available, no longer blocked by the chatter. You start rising to a level that you never thought possible a moment earlier. You’ll be having the best race on the biggest day when it counts most!

item.title: DEALING WITH FEAR
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I recently had an email exchange with one of our pro athletes, Janelle Morrison, about her upcoming race at Challenge Penticton. For those of you who do not know Janelle’s story, you must see the documentary about a tragic accident she was in a few years ago and her compelling comeback from it: http://www.asecondchancefilm.ca/index.html Last year she raced Penticton as an affirmation that yes, she is still alive, still able to compete. This year she’s looking for more. Not only has this season been about breaking the tug and pull of scar tissue that still lingers, but also about breaking the newsfeed from her internal conversations that do not serve her. But those old tapes can be just as tough to dissolve as are a handful of lingering physical issues left over from the accident.  The recent email Janelle sent me was detailing how she is going to approach each leg of her race later this very week. It was like a letter written by her wiser self to the part of her that is human and can be vulnerable to weakness and impatience and challenge. There was one key sentence about how she is going to deal with some of the inevitable noise that can go on inside on the marathon. She said, “Whatever is happening at this point, find it within yourself to overcome and rise above discomfort, fear, fatigue, anything you feel during this time”. It gave me immediate flashbacks to my days of racing and how I managed those exact three realities of competing. There are countless ways you can approach them so that they don’t derail your efforts. Hers was going to be to overcome them, no matter what. I had a subtly different, but significantly different way of handling those three very important issues. Rather than trying to overcome or push through them, I would to focus on putting together a super race effort in spite of discomfort, fear, fatigue. Here’s why they are so different. “Overcoming” requires fortitude and energy and being stronger than the challenge. Racing “in spite of” them only requires doing what you are there to do without paying a whole lot of attention to those three things. You don’t have to address them head on when racing in spite of their presence, regardless of their pull and tug and the way they can turn your focus away from your motivation to continue. You get to just go out there and build the greatness of your day one step at a time in spite of the presence of fear, fatigue, of discomfort. "In spite of" is simply remembering to focused on getting the job done regardless of discomfort, fear or fatigue. It takes the power out of them and requires none of your own power to overcome them because you are not overcoming them. You are simply effective even with them. “Overcoming” puts you in contest with yourself and those three things to see who will win out. “In spite of” allows your greatness to come forth even in the presence of discomfort or fear or fatigue because you can see that there really can be a way to give your best without being directly linked to the effect of those three things. “In spite of” is like you are all on a subway together going to the same destination. The first way of looking at them requires a conversation to be taking place between you and those three things the entire ride. That takes energy. The second enables you and those things to be sitting on the subway together, still going to the same destination, but you are both minding your own business. No conversation going on between you and them. You end up at the destination just the same but you got to go there without having to sit there and talk with them. It brings peace to your effort and greatness to the result. Janelle summed up the difference perfectly when I gave her my spin on it. She said, "Rising above/going beyond or overcoming" in the way I said it in the plan, is in a sense 'fighting what is happening' and disharmony is bound to occur, which is a total waste of energy. It means the mind is fighting for control over something.  The ego is in control...not the soul. Alternatively, "in spite of" means a surrender to what is happening while staying with that peaceful place within, regardless of the externals.” Can’t wait for Sunday’s Challenge Penticton! Mark

item.title: DOUBLE PEAKING
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Triathlon race options have really expanded in the last decade. Almost every weekend there is a significant event that if done well at could earn you a slot into an even bigger event later the same season. Usually though, that process is not a one-time do well affair. In fact the majority of athletes trying to qualify for a championship event end up racing at multiple venues to either accumulate points or to finish high enough so that the folks ahead already have theirs and one precious extra entry rolls down to their name. The upshot is that a lot of people end up having to hit a peak close enough to the big event they are shooting for that there is not enough time to really do a full cycle of training between the two. Here are a few thoughts on how to do just that for a variety of distances.
The biggest piece of a double peak is to recover enough from the first of the two before really going strong again with your training for the second peak. If your first race was an Olympic distance race or shorter, even a week easy should put the fire back in the engine and enable you to start back with serious training. If your first big peak was a half Ironman distance that period can extend out and be at minimum one week and likely up to two weeks of fairly easy workouts before you are really on target to hit the roads hard. Then for an Ironman, the recovery should be a minimum of two weeks and more likely three weeks of very easy recovery training.
The second most important thing to do is try to get some initial training that rebuilds your aerobic system, which likely will have fallen off a bit after your previous peak and recovery. You can think of it as going into a very short base building period like you would when you start back training at the beginning of the season, even if this “base” phase is only a week long.
The next element then is going to be keeping your anaerobic system activated just enough so that you still have speed but not doing too much that you never recover and end up at your second big race totally burned out. Lastly since the overall solid training is going to be much less in terms of total weeks than you would have done for a full cycle, the taper can also be cut shorter.
Here are some examples of the general theme of how you could do peaks of varying amounts between two big events.
Three weeks: one week recovery, one week moderate length training and speed, one week tapering back down.
Four weeks: one to two weeks recovery (closer to do if it was an IM), one to two weeks of regular training. If it is two weeks, the first week keep aerobic but build the miles, then the second week both endurance and speed. One week taper.
Five weeks: one to two weeks of recovery, two to solid weeks of training with first week mostly aerobic then the second both endurance work and speed. Then taper down the remaining time.
Six weeks: one to two weeks of recovery, two to three weeks of solid training, with the first week aerobic, then the remaining both endurance and speed. Taper down one to two weeks.
This gives you some basic guidelines to go on. Again, the top priority is getting some concentrated recovery immediately after that first peak. So save your biggest decadence until after peak number two, get plenty of sleep, and be active without it being taxing until you start back to training in earnest. Second priority is having your first part back to real training be aerobic to rebuild and reset that physiology. Then it will be time to do just a bit of speedwork to reactivate that system before going into your second and final taper. Remember that last taper will not need to be as long as it was if you had been training consistently hard for a few months in a row.
Best of luck!

item.title: GREAT BIKE, NOT SO GREAT RUN
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Coach,
I have been racing for over twenty years and have always found that my run is BY FAR my weakness event of the three. Intuitively I believe part of it is bike and swim pacing, but I also have just never been able to run fast...even for regular runs. With a lot of good training, my best 15K is just under an hour and I can't seem to get under 19:00 for a 5K no matter what I do. My Ironman PR is 10:03 (S: 59:47, B 5:08, R 3:44) at IM Florida. As you can see the run is 20-30 minutes slower than others with similar swim and bike splits.
When I train aerobically my pace for the bike is 19-20 mph but for the run is only 10-11 minute/mile. Doesn't this seem pretty imbalanced between the bike and the run?
Just a few personal stats, I am about 5’10” and weigh in on race day at 175 lbs.
Thank you!!
Stan
Dear Stan,
Yes, for sure your cycling speed and your run pace are not in line with each other. Running unfortunately is partially a factor of weight compared to your height. But the good news is that even a few pounds lighter can make a big difference (as long as the loss is not from losing lean muscle). While it is impossible to calculate exactly what the gains might be, there is some research that says that for every pound lost you run 2-second/mile faster. So for an Ironman distance event, if you raced closer to an ideal weight for your height, which is about 15 pounds less than you are now, that equates to a marathon that is almost fifteen minutes faster right there.
But running is not just a function of weight. It is also a function of body mechanics. If you are stiff in the flexibility needed for an open stride, your muscles will create resistance and reduce efficiency. So if you compare two people with the exact same weight and fitness, the one who is more flexible in the running stride will likely see a significantly faster time in their marathon in an Ironman.
In addition, mechanics is a huge factor. A heel striker will end up running slower than a midfoot striker. I don’t know what your run mechanics look like, but if your run cadence is low and you are a heel striker, you will not maximize those final minutes that you are hoping to gain.
So, what are my recommendations? See if you can gradually reduce body weight without losing lean muscle (this means less body fat that is lost at a pound a week), work on run form and mechanics and efficiency to gain a midfoot strike and a run cadence that is close to 90 foot strikes per minute (counted on one side), and lastly work on flexibility in the run stride.
I hope that helps,
Mark

item.title: IMPROVING YOUR MARATHON IN A TRIATHLON
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Coach,
I a probably like a lot of folks. I have had some good Ironman races, but I am hoping to improve my marathon by a fairly significant amount. Is this a pipedream or do I have a chance to get faster?
Marty,
 
Hi Marty,
The answer depends on a few things. The first is how your training pace is currently. There are just some hard to overcome realities about going faster in an Ironman, especially in Kona where I know you want to really up your game. Here is one reality check: people tend to be able to run about the same pace for their Ironman marathon as they run their long runs when timed in similar conditions to race day and run at a pace that is completely aerobic (not anaerobic). In your case, knowing your history, I know that you are able to average about 10-minute mile pace in your long runs, which is a 4:22 marathon. You are already running almost 20 minutes faster than that in your Ironman, so you are already beating the odds! Congratulations!!!
But regardless of that bit of time comparison you want to get faster. So here's a few things that may help get you more time. One is to slow just a very small percent on the bike to have more left in the legs for the run. This is a very tough call to figure out how to do because of conditions, etc. But Ironman is one race where gaining a bit of time on the bike can mean a lot slower split on the run. Fortunately the opposite is true in that just a slight bit slower on the bike can often mean a significantly faster marathon. So assess if you have been pushing the pace on the bike just a bit too much, and if so, make it your plan in your next Ironman to dial the effort back just slightly and then see how that translates once you get to your feet on the marathon.
A second thing is going to be gaining efficiency in your run form. Part of this is getting on and off your feet faster. One of best drills for this is to stand on one foot with your eyes closed, arms at the side. Try it! Once you have that, then bend your knee just slightly and lower your body down 3-4 inches, still with the eyes closed. Try that one! And then finally once you have that, straighten your leg once again, all with eyes closed. This works the landing, the load of the muscles and then the push off of the run motion in a way that develops a quicker on and off the foot time via better proprioceptor action, and that is what will get you a faster run time.
The second aspect of efficiency is the actual force with which you come in contact with the ground and the amount of up and down in your overall stride. I tried to basically run by rotating from my hips and shoulders but having my head having almost no up and down motion. So if you think of trying to keep your head from going up and down with each footstrike and push off as well as having your feet just coming in contact with the ground with the absolute minimum of impact, then there will be less muscle tear down. It's the muscle teardown that slows you down a lot in the marathon.
Third thing, flexibility work in the run stride. Not sure if you are flexible or not, but the less your body has to work against itself for each stride the faster you go for free.
Fourth, do functional strength work. The move that is best for gaining functional strength for running is one where you do a step up onto a box with weights one leg at a time. This will really help you to get more out of each step in the run as it builds balance in the push phase. It doesn't matter how strong your glutes and legs are, if you get just that little bit of wobble in the ankle/knee/foot as it all tries to find a stable platform to push off of, then that power is lost. But if you develop your balance in the push as well as gain power, then you are faster with less mass to carry around.
Lastly, dial in your race nutrition so that you have good calories for the marathon. Calories are king in the marathon. Without them you just cannot run that fast.
Okay, I hope that gives a few things to chew on.
Mark

item.title: ISSUES WITH RACE DAY NUTRITION
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Question: I have done a few Ironman races over the past two years (four to be exact) and I have had the same experience of bonking in each one of them. The feeling seems to start when I’ve got about an hour left on the bike and then just gets worse as I go through the marathon. Some of the races I start to feel better after I go through the run then jog then walk phase and have a chance to get in more calories. But even then I still can’t seem to nail it in terms of steady energy levels throughout the race. Any suggestions?
 
Answer: There are a few things that can give you the feeling of bonking. One is definitely from being low on calories. Here is some math to consider. You can burn up to about 700 cal/hour when going at race pace, but can only absorb roughly 350/hour. That puts a person at a calorie deficit over an Ironman especially when you talk about carbohydrate calories. Keep in mind that even if you are racing aerobically and getting a lot of your calories from fat for fuel, that fat still needs carbohydrate present to initiate breaking it down for energy. And if you are going at high-energy outputs, the bulk of your calories are going to come from carbs. You only start the race with about 2,000 calories stored as glycogen in the first place though. Once those are gone, if you have not replaced them steadily throughout the event you will end up, yes, walking simply because there is no ready source of stored fuel to go fast, and even though your body will certainly have lots of fat still stashed away, without carbohydrate it cannot easily break it down for energy. Thus the bonk.
The solution for this is to first and foremost regulate your pace so that you stay steady and keep the energy equation shifted toward fat burning to help spare stored glycogen.
Next look at your source of carbohydrate in your energy drink that you are taking in on the course. Likely its main source for carbohydrate is maltodextrin. This form of carbohydrate can have a pass through rate of up to about 50% meaning that about 50% of what you take in never gets broken down and absorbed into your body. It just passes through the digestive system untouched and never gets to the working muscle. The solution here is to seek out a sports drink that has glucose in it as one of the sources of your carb. Glucose (or dextrose as it is often called in food) gets absorbed passively and is basically 100% absorbed because it doesn't have to breakdown before going into the blood.
A second reason you can feel like you are bonking is from being low on sodium. When your sodium gets depleted you can have that same sensation of wanting to go faster but not being able to coordinate your muscles, your mind can be wandering and you feel low energy.
The solution to this is to take sodium on the race course. I suggest a sodium tablet that you can actually taste the sodium if you suck on it in your mouth. This helps you to regulate very accurately how much you need. Let the tablet dissolve in your mouth until you reach the point where you body says “enough”. Any that is left you can spit out. A general rule of thumb to start experimenting with sodium during your training is to take in about 350mg/hour. This total should take into consideration the amount that is already in your sports drink.
A third reason you can feel like you are bonking is from being low on magnesium. This is a mineral that like sodium is necessary for going fast. However, unlike sodium that can be basically replaced on the spot, magnesium only gets stored up over time with good diet or even supplementation. Foods high in magnesium include vegetables, beans and nuts. Stock up on those foods on a daily basis in your meals.
Then finally, the last reason one can feel like they are bonking is from muscle breakdown. There can be a tipping point in any Ironman where your leg muscles (mostly quads) start to have enough breakdown that your self-preservation genetics are going to start to give you the sensation that you just can’t push anymore and you start to slow. If you have a power meter or a heart rate monitor you can try focusing on getting your output back up to what you were sustaining earlier in the race to see if you can give a modest override to this natural occurrence. In tandem with doing this make sure you are also staying on top of your calories and sodium intake.
If nothing is working to get you back up to pace, drop things down a notch or two and see if there is a slower pace that is sustainable without having to go to a full drop off in effort.
Regardless of who you are, in an Ironman there is going to be some drop off in output over the course of the day. The key is to try to pace the early stages of the race conservatively so that you push that point into the latest stages of the race as possible. Ideally hold back enough in the first three quarters of the Ironman so that the drop off in pace is negligible in that final and critical last quarter of the event.
I hope that helps,
Mark

item.title: LONG BIKE AND LONG RUN WORKOUTS
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Coach,
I am training for an Ironman and have a question about how to best do a long bike/long run combo. My training partners are saying that it’s best to do say a long run one day then a long ride the next so that you can go fast in the long run, and that’s how you are going to go fast in an Ironman. But I seem to have read somewhere that it’s better to do the combo with the long bike one day then a long run the next so that you do it with some fatigue in your legs. Do you have an opinion on this? Jeffrey
 
Dear Jeffrey,
This is a debate that often comes up in coaching circles. There is truth to the concept of run one day then bike the next. You indeed will be able to run a bit faster on fresher legs. However, the real question is if this is what will get you to your best Ironman marathon split. My opinion is that it will not, and here is why.
When you are in your race and come off the bike you will with out a doubt be running on legs that are far from fresh. As everyone has experienced it is very different running off the bike than it is to run on completely fresh legs. When rested and fresh it is very easy to maintain good running form, a good cadence rate, and proper foot strike with each stride. When you are tired, all three of those things can fall completely apart. Your shoulders can come up and your upper body might tighten to compensate for tired legs. Your cadence rate can drop drastically. And finally you may go from an efficient midfoot strike to one where your foot hits the ground heel first, which is like putting on the brakes with each stride.
If you do your long bike one day then your long run the next you will still have some fatigue in your legs, which will force you to start to develop the ability to hold all three of those key running elements in check when tired. It is not important to cover a lot of ground on that long run, but rather to learn how to deal with fatigue and hold your overall form and keep it relaxed, to maintain a good cadence rate and to hold a midfoot strike. If you always run on fresh legs for your long run, you will have less chance to work with this.
So then the next question that often comes up is that if it is good to run your long runs on slightly tired legs, then why not run it on completely tired legs and do the run directly after the long bike? Again a good question! The answer to this is that it puts you at severe risk of injury. Some fatigue is good. Long ride dead legs fatigue, however, is over the top. You can certainly do some bricks after a long bike with runs of up to about fifty-minutes to train your body to transition from cycling to running on those longer days. But doing a long run after a long bike is excessive and from what I have seen and experienced gives very little translatable fitness that will help you in your Ironman.
I hope that helps,
Mark Allen

item.title: OFF SEASON RECOVERY
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dear Coach,
I just finished my final race of the year. What should I be doing now? I know I need to rest, but I'm afraid of losing my fitness that I worked so hard to get this season. Any suggestions?
Sandy Dear Sandy
This is a great question. The off season is as key to your racing success as the hard training is. What this time of year should be focused on initially is just recharging your batteries. This happens through cutting back on training and doing very easy unstructured sessions. The amount of unstructured time really depends on how deep you went to the well to come up with the race performances you did during the past season and how much of a toll the training to get ready took on your energy reserves. But in general it's good to take at least three weeks of very unstructured exercise time after your final race to start to put the energy back in the tank.
During that time just go out and move simply because it feels good to be outside. These sessions should NOT be thought of as training or as getting you close to anything you would call fitness. These exercise sessions can be doing your three triathlon sports or you can mix it up with other things like mountain biking, hiking, or just about anything else that gets you moving.
Here is why this is so important. First there is a deep energy reserve that gets depleted during your season that needs to have time to charge back up. That doesn't happen overnight. It takes weeks. Easy light movement can actually help that happen fairly fast. But real training will prevent it from taking place. It's like having an injury that you can't see or feel but that is there and needs time to get rid of by cutting way back on your normal routine.
Secondly a body gets used to all levels of training, and after a while stops responding as quickly with fitness gains. To go to the next level in the upcoming year you must decondition some, meaning as great as you must have felt in that final race, you have to come down off that peak if your body is going to then continue to respond to new training and get even more fit the following year.
I used to take from the time Ironman was over in October until around the first of the year as this key unstructured exercise part of my season. I would run about every other day 20-30 minutes, surf a few times a week and maybe get on my bike 1-2 times a week for about an hour. That would be a good lifestyle program for most people! But it was well below what I did during my peak training. And I did all of it very easy with no intention of it giving me fitness. It was just more to be outside and enjoy the fall and early winter weather. And with that, when I started back up with real training, I was indeed out of shape compared to what I would be in during the racing part of the year, but I was also full of energy and ready to go back at it once again.
Enjoy the down time! Mark

item.title: THE MENTAL TAPER
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Often your mind is the toughest tool to get sharpened for race day. Your body will come around on its own given enough rest and keeping your whole ball of wax fairly low key race week. But the space between the ears with all the extra time resting during a good taper often ends up going into overdrive with analyzing the race and how it's going to go and worrying about all the other competitors and wondering if indeed you are ready, and did I forget any of my race day equipment and am I resting enough or too much, and oh that person looks so much more fit than me...
You know the drill. The catch is that race week and the anxiety one can feel during it is exactly what allows you raise your game to stratospheric proportions. If you are absolutely and totally relaxed, your race day will likely be exactly like a training day and no more.
Angela Naeth, who is racing her first Ironman tomorrow at Lake Tahoe, asked me about this a week ago. She wrote, "When you are thinking ahead about the race and feel stuck on fear, frustration, etc how did you align yourself with seeking perfection?"
This was a great question to be asking because it's the real world stuff that can come up and creep in when the taper hits and you have a lot of extra time on your hands to contemplate the biggest day in your sports calendar.
Here's what I responded with: "Well, here are the mechanics of it. First, hang out with yourself and go through every scenario that worries you about the race and figure out how you will deal with it or work around it. Next, go have a conversation with the lake and/or the mountains there in Tahoe. They will help you.
"Next keep in mind that about 90% of the junk rolling around in the brain that is bothersome is just mental theater and has nothing to do with reality and especially has nothing to do with your ability to deal with the situations if they should happen in real life.
"Finally, keep in mind that perfection comes through action, and right now you are in the limbo state of non-action leading up to the actual race. You are just waiting, percolating, resting, regenerating so that when the time comes on Sunday you can then go into action one step at a time and be a part of however the race unfolds.
"And ultimately aligning with perfection comes when you realize there is just no way to wrap your brain around an Ironman, when you realize you are not in control of the outcome, but are there to be a vehicle for someone pursuing greatness and excellence and steadiness and commitment and total engagement regardless of the outer look, and when all that happens it becomes perfection."

item.title: THREE TIPS FOR A GREAT IRONMAN RUN
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The run in a triathlon is so different than running alone. When a person is fresh their cadence, footstrike and force that drives them forward is often generated differently than when the are tired from the swim and bike, their legs feel like lead and their biomechanics start in a broken down state. But that does not mean you have to run slowly as a triathlete! Here are a few golden rules to help you with your run.
Golden Rule #1. Form is of utmost important. If you are running fresh, there are a lot of secondary muscles that can makeup for poor running form and keep you going in a pretty straight line without much deviation and body collapse. If you are tired, every small instability and imperfection in your foot strike and overall balance will be magnified.
There are two great drills you can do to develop both proper foot strike and good balance in the micro muscles that will enable you to get on and off your feet quicker with each stride. The foot strike drill is easy. Take your shoes off and run barefoot on a track or grassy flat field. It only takes a minute or two of doing this to get the sensation of a perfect midfoot strike. Feel how without your shoes you land perfectly directly on your midfoot. If you are a heal striker, which slows you down just slightly with every stride, this will correct it. Now put your shoes back on and try to recreate that same midfoot strike feel and the lightness that comes with it. You can do this drill a few times a week initially until you start to get the hang of it.
Now for the balance. Take your shoes off again. Stand on one foot with your arms at your side and the leg straight that you are standing on. Now close your eyes. You will likely feel a bit of wobble when you do this. It’s normal at first. This part of the drill (and there are three parts) will teach your body how to accept the weight of your body without any instability. Next with your eyes closed bend that same knee and lower yourself down just a few inches or centimeters. Again you will likely feel lots of wobble. This develops the part of your run stride where you are loading up your leg with your full body weight and getting ready to push off. Then the final part of the drill, again keeping your eyes closed, push back up to a straight leg stance on that one leg. Again some wobble? This part develops the stability of the push off the ground so that all your force is directed into a forward direction and none is lost in the wobble. Do this every day for a week one leg then the other then back to the first and so on for about 20-30 seconds in each position on each leg until you start to gain the ability to lock in to a stable position in each part of the run.
Golden Rule #2. The endurance you need to run off the bike is built in your longer rides and bricks. This is especially important to keep in mind for your brick workouts. It is not necessary to ride say 5 hours then run another 2 hours to get ready for an Ironman. The ability to keep going is built by doing simple long rides. The ability to run well right away off the bike comes by doing brick workouts where you finish the bike and then run anywhere from 20-50 minutes. This type of workout teaches your body that the bike ride is not the end of the day, and the run after it develops the patterning to be ready to run right away after the bike. That transition in muscles happens in the first minutes of running. I didn’t figure this out until the year I won Ironman for the first time. Before that I would do a long ride one day, then a long run the next. But when I got to Kona and got off the bike I realized my body was ready for a big meal and a nap, not a run. So in 1989, the first year I was able to win the Ironman in Hawaii, I did a lot of long bike, short run bricks. It was the first year I actually felt good and ready to run the marathon!
Golden Rule #3. A fast triathlon run is only possible if you take care of yourself on the bike in the race. That means pacing and calorie intake. Many people who are strong cyclists try going for it on the bike then hoping for the best on the run. Usually this doesn’t work! Regardless of your swimming and cycling abilities, conserve just a little of your energy for the run. This is especially key in longer races. It is better to cycling say 5 minutes slower to ensure you can run well in the marathon if an Ironman. The difference, as you know, between a good marathon and a bad one at the end of an Ironman can be 30-60 minutes. But usually a good and a bad bike will only be 5-10 minutes different. Conserve on the bike to have a great run.
Then the second part of taking care of yourself for the run means keeping the calories going in so that your tank if full rather than running on fumes by the end of the bike. Generally 300-350 cal/hour will do the trick. But practice in training. Keep track of about how many calories you need during a long bike ride so that when you get off the bike you feel fueled up enough to go for a run rather than feeling the need to have a huge meal.

item.title: TIMELINE OF RACE NUTRITION
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This question came from one of our athletes a while ago. It deals with the timing of race nutrition. Here is his question and my response.
Dear Coach,
I have been working on my race day nutrition for an Ironman that I have coming up. I have one question about how the timing of how to take in my calories. I would imagine that having kind of a regular input of calories suits the body better than having like 300 calories all at once and then going an hour without anything. On the other hand I have the feeling that when I am continuously eating, there is never a time when I feel really well because my stomach is always having to digest. Is this more an individual issue? Is it best to take in say 200 calories every half hour, or 400 once an hour or to try to take in something like 100 calories every fifteen minutes? Thanks for your advice.
Steve
______
Hi Steve,
The answer to this question is somewhat dependent on your body. Some people do best when they take in a bunch of calories all at once while others need to dribble it in regularly at shorter intervals. The answer to which type of body you have might be discovered if you think about how you eat throughout the day. Do you do best by having a few giant meals or are you the type of person who is continually grazing throughout the day but never eat huge meals? That is one aspect to consider.
Here is another as it relates to how we take in calories. Our bodies have absorption cycles. At one point you can absorb a ton of calories, then a little while later it can be tough to absorb much. So if a person is on a regular short interval feeding schedule indeed some times you will get calories going in when your body is ready, but other times your sports drink or energy bars will likely just sit there. When I raced I looked at the total amount of calories I wanted to take in during each leg of the race and made that the goal, but didn’t have a specific schedule that I followed, which allowed me to be more closely aligned with those natural absorption ups and downs. So if I had say two bottles of calories I wanted to get in on the bike, I would just keep an eye on them and try to get them in before the end of the bike, but sort of let my body tell me when to take in the majority of them.
The last thought has to do with the reality of your blood sugar at any one point. You can also monitor your pace and heart rate. If you suddenly see that your pace and your heart rate are dropping, that is usually a good sign that you are getting low on calories and need to get them in right then regardless of whether or not you are hungry.
I hope that helps, Mark

item.title: Coaching plans
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Exercise Descriptions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1) Lateral Pull-downs Grasp bar with arms straight and slightly wider than shoulder width apart. Push chest forward, arch lower back. Pull bar down in front of head to shoulder level.               2) Leg Extensions Sit on machine. Rest shin pads just above ankles. Line knee with pivot point of machine. Extend both legs fully to make a straight line.               3) Leg Curls Lie face-down on machine bench. Place leg pad just above ankles. Keep legs slightly bent. Contract fully. Keep hips on pad at all times.           4) Bench Press Lie face-up on bench, hands slightly wider than shoulder width apart, with the bar above mid-chest. Lower bar to one inch above mid chest. Keep lower back on bench at all times.           5) Squats Stand with legs wider than shoulders. Arch lower back. Keep weight over heels at all times. Push glutes back. Bend knees until upper leg is parallel to floor. Knees should never extend in front of the toes.               6) Dumbbell Pullover—Laying face up on a bench hold dumbbell with both hands directly above chest. Lower the weight to just past horizontal. In this exercise the breathing is opposite of all other lifts. NOTE: On this you breathe out when you lower the weight, then breathe in when you lift it. All other exercises you breathe out when you lift the weight and breathe in when you lower it.         7) Reverse Lunges Stand with legs together. Rest bar comfortably on upper back. Step back, extending leg out behind. Return to standing position, dragging the toes of the extended foot on the floor on the way back up.               8) Side Lateral Raise Hold a weight in each hand with weight facing your body. Extend arms out and up sideways to just below horizontal. At that point turn palms upward, then continue the lift touching the weights together above your head. When lowering keep palms turned upward until just above horizontal. At that point turn palms downward and continue the lower of the weight.             9) Calf Raises Place one foot on a step and the other raised just slightly off the step. Hold the weight in the arm on the same side as the calf you are working. Raise heel. When lowering back down, only go until you feel a moderate stretch in the calf. DO NOT OVERSTRETCH THE CALF ON THE LOWERING.               10) Bicep Curls Start with weight lowered, elbows tight against the side of your body and arms slightly bent. Contract arms up, still supporting your weight with your biceps. Keep elbows locked tight against your side.               11) Tricep Extension Grasp ropes with both hands keeping elbows next to body and not extended back. Press down and out with both hands continuing to keep elbows in close and parallel to the line of the body.               12) Leg Press Sit on the sled with your knees bent and feet roughly shoulder width apart. Extend legs fully.             Then finish with:
  • Back Raises: Lay on your stomach. Raise one leg and the opposite arm and hold for 15–30 seconds. Then switch and raise the other leg and opposing arm. Repeat each group twice, rest 10 seconds, then lift both arms and legs at the same time, again holding them off the ground for 15–30 seconds. This will develop the lower back muscles.
  • Sit-ups: Sit-ups should work all four areas of the abdominal region, which are the lower, middle, and upper abs as well as the sides, or obliques, of the abdominal muscles. Life Strength sit-ups should not exceed more than 15 repetitions in any of the regions. Doing hundreds of sit-ups can give you abs of steel, but it can also cause a build up of lactic acid, which will turn off your fat burning system and overdevelop the muscles around your diaphragm, which will cause your breathing to be shallow and restricted.
  • Modified push-ups: Flip back over onto your stomach and do eight push-up raises. This is a regular push-up motion except that you keep your hips on the ground. This lengthens the muscles that attach to the lower back, which can get shortened by sitting for long periods of time and can cause lower back pain. Do three push-ups looking straight up, two looking left, two looking right, and then one more looking straight up again.
  At-Home Program If you are unable to get to a gym to do the strength exercises there are ways you can mimic many of the lifts in the gym program at home with a minimum of equipment. Here is what you will need:
  • Rubber stretch cords (also called resistance bands) with a door attachment
  • Hand-held weights (choose various sizes, from three-pounders to roughly twenty pounds)
  • Ankle weights
  • A sturdy chair
  • A flat thin bench (optional)
Each of these tools can help you simulate strength exercises from the gym. You can do these exercises exclusively with resistance bands or with a combination of bands and hand weights. Again, if you use weights, I recommend getting an assortment of sizes, from three pounds up. Here is a description of how to do each exercise at home: 1) Lateral Pull-Down: with the stretch cords or bands attached to the top of a doorway you can simulate the lat pull-downs. 2) Leg Extensions: to do the leg extensions while sitting, attach ankle weights to do the lift. If using bands or cords, secure one end to the base of a chair and the other end to your ankles. While sitting, extend leg up. Do one leg at a time. 3) Leg Curls: same as leg extensions, but stand facing the chair for stability when you perform the lift. 4) Bench Press: use hand weights or put bands around your back. Lie flat on a bench and raise arms up straight. 5) Squats: holding weights in your hands, go through the squat move as described in #5 above. With bands or cords, stand on them and put bands over your shoulders to create resistance during the lift. 6) Dumbbell Pullover—Lying face up on a bench or edge of a bed hold dumbbell with both hands directly above chest. Lower the weight to just past horizontal. In this exercise the breathing is opposite of all other lifts. NOTE: On this you breathe out when you lower the weight, then breathe in when you lift it. All other exercises you breathe out when you lift the weight and breathe in when you lower it. 7) Reverse Lunges—Stand with legs together. Rest bar comfortably on upper back, or without a bar hold weights in both hands. Step back, extending leg out behind. Return to standing position, dragging the toes of the extended foot on the floor on the way back up. 8) Side Lateral Raise: raise weights as in #8 above. If you use bands or cords, step on them and raise arms out to the side only going to horizontal. 9) Calf Raises: use a step in your house as support for your foot to lower from. 10) Bicep Curls: same as #10 above, sitting in a chair or using a home bench. If using bands or cords, stand on one end of them, then lift one arm at a time. 11) Tricep Extension—Attach stretch cords out in front of you. Bend over and start with both hands just about mid-chest keeping elbows next to body and not extended back. Press back with both hands continuing to keep elbows in close and parallel to the line of the body. If you are using a weight, start on the ground on your knees with upper body supported by one hand on the ground. Have weight in other hand hanging directly down, then press back to full extension. 12) Leg Press: Using stretch cords, lie on back with cords around lower back and feet in loops. Push up with legs until fully extended.

item.title: Strength Training
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Strength Training

Strength training is one of the most commonly overlooked tools available to improve your performance with a minimum of additional training time. A well-executed strength program can actually allow you to cut up to 25% out of your aerobic training and have even better results! I have boiled the program down to what I consider to be the 12-key exercises necessary to develop overall body fitness for triathlons. The strength program is to be done two day per week. This is a combination that maximizes the benefits to you from the time spent in the gym. The exercises and order are as follows:
  1. Lateral Pull-Downs
  2. Leg Extensions
  3. Leg Curls
  4. Bench Press
  5. Squats
  6. Dumbbell Pullover
  7. Reverse Lunges
  8. Side Lateral Raises
  9. Calf Raise
  10. Bicep Curl
  11. Triceps
  12. Leg Press
Each exercise should be done to a count of two on the contraction or lifting of the weight and a count of four when lowering the weight. Form is of utmost importance when doing the exercises. Isolation of each muscle group is the goal. Breath out on the lifting the weight and in on the lowering of the weight. Note: The one exception is the dumbbell pullover where the breathing is reversed (breathe out when lowering the weight and in when lifting it).

The Four Phases of Strength Training

The strength program is divided into four distinct phases. Each one is designed to work different aspects of overall strength. Also by changing the form of stress on the muscles, there will be continuous development of strength throughout the entire program! Phase One: Adaptation (1x12-15 repetitions). During this phase the goal is to adapt the body to the stress and motion of lifting. Each exercise is to be done as follows: one set of 12-15 repetitions. The correct weight for each exercise will allow you to feel like you could have done 1-3 more repetitions with good form at the end of the set. The weight is too heavy if you are feeling a strong burn in the muscles at the end of the set, or if you do not feel you could have done a few more repetitions at the weight you chose. Phase Two:Endurance (2x12-15 repetitions). During this phase an increase to two sets will happen, with each set still at 12-15 repetitions. Again, the correct weight is one that allows you to complete the two sets knowing you could have done 1-3 more repetitions with good form and without any major burning in the muscles. Phase Three: Power (three sets 10-8-6). Feel the Burn! This phase is where the largest improvements in strength come. It is also when the sluggishness that weights can cause will carry over most into your swimming, cycling, and running. So don’t expect to feel like Carl Lewis at the same time you’re lifting like Arnold Schwarzenegger! During the Power Phase, the exercises are divided up into two groups. On the first strength workout of the week five exercises will be powered with the three sets: lateral pull-downs, leg extensions, leg curls, dumbbell pullovers and leg press. The powered exercises are done in three sets instead of two, and the repetitions change to one set of 10, one of 8, and a third of 6. The correct weight is one that will end the final set at your maximum effort. The remaining seven exercises are kept at 2 sets of 12-15 just like in the Endurance Phase. Then on the second strength workout of the week, the following four different exercises will do the three set maximum effort: bench press, squats, biceps, and triceps. And as in the first day, all other eight exercises remain as in Endurance at 2x12-15 repetitions. The Power Phase is about maximum effort. People find that the weight needed to do this is 10-25% more than the weight used for good form during the Endurance Phase.

Day 1

  • Power Lateral Pull-Downs (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Power Leg Extensions (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Power Leg Curls (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Bench Press (2x12-15)
  • Squats (2x12-15)
  • Power Dumbbell Pullover (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Lunges (2x12-15)
  • Side Lateral Raises (2x12-15)
  • Calf Raises (2x12-15)
  • Power Bicep Curl (2x12-15)
  • Triceps (2x12-15)
  • Leg Press (1x10,1x8,1x6)

Day 2

  • Lateral Pull-Downs (2x12-15)
  • Leg Extensions (2x12-15)
  • Leg Curls (2x12-15)
  • Power Bench Press (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Power Squats (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Dumbbell Pullover (2x12-15)
  • Lunges (2x12-15)
  • Side Lateral Raises (2x12-15)
  • Calf Raises (2x12-15)
  • Bicep Curl (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Power Triceps (1x10,1x8,1x6)
  • Leg Press (2x12-15)
Note: Not all exercises are powered. Side Lateral Raises, Lunges and Calf Raises all have a chance of causing injury if powered incorrectly. The risk is not worth the benefit. Phase Four: Chisel (2x12 repetitions). This is when all of the strength that has been gained will be honed with repetitions that simulate the speed of muscle contraction during racing. In the Chisel Phase, lighten the weight back down to the same or slightly less weight than what was used during the Endurance Phase. Do two sets of 12 repetitions to the count of two on both the contraction and the relaxation. This is a fast paced action, very anaerobic in its feel. The weight should be chosen so that it feels light yet become challenging at the end of set two due to a mild lactic acid build up. Failure starts to come from the speed of the move, not the load on the apparatus that is being lifted. Again, focus on good form, and make sure that you could still have done one or two repetitions at the end of the second set.
