item.title: Tips for the New Year
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
For many of you, now is the time to relaunch back into planning for your upcoming season, getting the training dialed in and figuring out what might take you to a new level in 2016. Here are a few thoughts on how to do all of those things and set yourself up for your best season ever!

"The final step is possible only because of the thousands taken before it." (From The Art of Competition)

Plan

Before you dive into your first serious training sessions of the year, take time to set your race schedule. What will be your "A" race of the year, your top priority that ultimately everything else is helping you focus your time and energies toward? There may be a couple of "A" races, each successive one dependent on how you did in the previous race (a likely scenario for those who are trying to qualify for a championship event and may need more than one race to get the result that will get you there). Ultimately all of your focus and training should work backwards from that top goal race in terms of your planning for the season, ending up with the last piece figuring out how you will begin your training today. Here is an example. Maybe you have a key goal race in October that you want to be the biggest priority of your year. Okay, great! Now back things up in your mind and your planning. How will you have your best day on that one day? Likely because you were fit enough and fast enough to have an amazing run split. Well, how did you do that? You did it because you had more bike fitness than you showed in the race and used that little bit extra to come off the bike fresh so that you could have the run of your life. Well then, how did you come off the bike fresh? Partially because your swim fitness went up a notch and instead of just surviving the swim, you came out in great position without having to go to the well to do it, which set you up to be fresh starting the bike. Wonderful! How did you get that fitness? Continue backing your vision up throughout the year to see how you did that. Include other races that you will sprinkle in that will help you gain the extra fitness needed for your grand finale, just enough other races to help you and not too many to tire you out.

Dial In Your Training

Now that you have a vision of where you want to end up, you likely also have some ideas of what will get you there in your training. The beginning of the season when you are just getting back in shape is an extremely rich period where some subtle but very important patterns can be set that will help you out at the end of the year. The most critical aspect to dial in is your patterns of movement. How do you move? Where are you generating your power from in the water and on the bike, and what are you doing that will get you on and off your feet quicker running? When you are getting back in shape you generally lack the fitness to overcome any inefficiencies of movement, which means that they show up more quickly. When you are in great shape you can overcome most issues of poor mechanics because of a strong engine. But now is a priceless time to reveal the inefficiencies that will surface and correct them. In the water ask yourself if you have an abundance of upper body strength. If you do, then you can go the route of Michael Phelps and have the lowest stroke count out there. But if you lack lots of upper body strength, then your speed will have to come via a higher cadence rate mixed in with just enough hip rotation to help you gain power from each stroke. These next two drills were in last month's newsletter, but I want to present them again because they are incredibly helpful. The catch is that you have to actually practice them to extract their richness. Plus this is the time of year to really use them to gain efficiency and generate power in your bike and run before your training picks back up to my larger volumes and more intensity. On the bike try out a drill where you put your bike on a stationary trainer and spin with your eyes closed. Can you feel your glutes engaging in the power phase of the pedal stroke? If not you are likely using your quads as the dominant force generator, and those muscles will fail in a race. Your glutes will never tire! Here's a drill to help you learn how to engage those powerful muscles. While in the aero position try rocking your hips forward by pulling your belly button closer to your vertebrae. This would be the opposite sensation of pushing your belly button toward your top tube and arching your lower back. If you can do this, you will also feel your glutes being engaged in the power phase of your pedal stroke. And with that you have immense ability to generate power and speed on the bike! When you are out on your first runs of the year, count your cadence rate. Ideally you should be hitting close to 90 foot strikes per minute counted on one side. If you are at 70 or 80, you are likely either over-striding or you have some instability on your landing and can't get off your feet efficiently. So the first task is to try to shorten your stride length and see if you are able to increase your cadence rate. Secondly, try this drill: stand on one foot with your eyes closed and your leg straight, arms relaxed at your side. Work on this until you feel stable. Now do the other foot. Go back and forth a number of times until you gain better stability. You may notice that one side is easy and the other is wobbly. Work more with the wobbly side! This is the landing part of the run stride. Next, still with your eyes closed and on one leg, bend your knee to lower yourself just a few inches. Again try to gain stability without wobbling. This is the load phase of the run stride. Finally, again with your eyes closed on one leg, push back up into a straight leg position and be stable. This is the toe-off phase of the run stride. When you can do this with your eyes closed you will find that the speed you can get on and off your feet while running will dramatically improve!

Your New Level

Finally, what will take you to your next level this season? Is it doing some consistent strength work? Might it be finding a better balance between training and life? Could it be absorbing your training better, which could come from doing slightly less than you think you need so that you are recovering and not wasted all the time? What about working on nutrition? Is there one pattern in your eating that you know does not support your goals at the end of the year? If so, then give it up! Replace your food addiction with how good you feel without it! What about your mindset? Do you tend to get in your own way? How will you become your own best ally on race day? How will you find that internal quiet that is the most powerful place to race from? Being quiet is definitely not like highway hypnosis! It is more training yourself to be quiet and tuned into the rhythm of movement. Having a quiet mind is shifting your focus away from letting every little sensation going on in your body affect your outlook to having a focus that is aware of all those signals but that is like an outside observer who isn't going to be swayed by them and what they could mean in terms of affecting your race. It's having a focus that is like seeing 360 degrees without having to look around to see everything. Having a quiet mind is having a sense that you are in the center of the bigger picture of life rather than in a race that in the moment may be nothing like you had hoped. A quiet mind is staying fully engaged and giving everything you have in the moment at hand, and the next and then the one after that without the worry of how it will turn out, and doing this especially if achieving your dreams seems impossible. It's responding to the situation rather than trying to control it. It's expansive rather than contractive. Try working with one of these concepts at a time and see if you can experience it in your next training session. Then pick the next one in the following session to see if you can experience that as well until you have gone through each of them. Then you will likely have a sense of what having a quiet mind in the middle of movement, of effort, even in the middle of a painful speed session or an impossible comeback in a race can be and how it can transform your efforts into the experience of a lifetime!

"Inner peace first, then outer results. Not the other way around." (From The Art of Competition)

item.title: Two Odd Tidbits You Probably Won't Find Anywhere Else
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
Human athletic performance is a complicated act with nearly endless processes that influence other processes, that in the end result in something we call a great race. Science scrapes apart the individual pieces to help us understand how we might improve enough elements in our preparation to bring about a jump in performance when it counts most. But as most of you know that miraculous machine called the body has way more going on than a lab can explain or contain. Simple example? How about that sore knee you had last year? If we were able to expert out all aspects of what the body was doing, we would never get injured, we'd never have a bad day, and likely we would never be surprised when we had a lifetime best performance even though an analysis of our logbook might not warrant such greatness! So the search continues for ways to better the best of our time, the best of our personal history. Some of that knowledge is going to be found through trial and error and personal experience in ways that no scientific paper could predict. I had to use this less-than-linear approach in the early years of my racing simply because there was no body of knowledge about how to combine three sports into a single endeavor that could last up to seventeen hours! Out of those years of testing the untested, there were two pretty big discoveries that I want to share with you. They are odd tidbits that you will probably be hard pressed to find much, if anything, said about them anywhere else. These are things that I have seen to be rock solid even though no research paper that I know of can corroborate them. Interested? Read on...

Odd Tidbit #1

This piece of underground knowledge has to do with the switch point where running becomes your friend. You see, some people find they struggle with running even after years of steady training in a sport that is based on something very natural for a human being to do. Others, on the other hand, cross over into a whole different realm where they often forget that they are even running while doing it. Their mind floats through random thoughts, they might be aware of their breathing or cadence, but rarely are they struggling to run. Their run is a freedom in and of itself, which is in sharp contrast to someone who is always experiencing this simple movement as somewhat painful or uncomfortable and certainly not a fluid oneness that allows their minds to just wander and be free! So how do you go from struggling to serenity with your running? More training? More weekly miles? Longer runs? Faster paces, slower paces? If you are an endurance animal, the answer has to do with a magical distance of around eight miles. When a person starts running, even a mile or two can seem like a marathon. But over time as you run more you will likely start to see that a small portion of it can become "comfortable" in that it's not a struggle to cover the distance. Then you might start to build up your long runs so that they are six miles, then twelve miles, then even upwards of eighteen to twenty miles. But not all of that is going to be "comfortable". In fact, you might be able to bust your way to a very long run but still feel like there is no ease anywhere, even in something short like a three-mile jog. The critical key is to adapt over time with a steady running diet of shorter runs, longer runs and some speed. Eventually there can come a point where about eight-miles is something you are able to cover with very little mental energy. Once you hit that level your running as a whole will start to take on a totally different complexion. Getting enough of a running base in your body to the point where eight miles becomes an ease seems to tip the scale in favor of running being your friend rather than something awkward, boring, or potentially injurious. For me this process took about three years from the time I started running as part of my triathlon training to get to the point where it switched and running took on ease. During that time I did longer runs. I raced in Kona several times. But it was not until my body adapted enough to have eight-miles feel fairly easy that running switched from being like a foreign language that I barely understood to a sport that I had fluency in. Toward the middle of that third year of running I noticed that eight-miles was starting to feel comfortable. My mind would wander and I was only aware of the rhythm of my running rather than the pain or awkwardness of it. I felt fluid. Then all my runs started to take on an element of that fluency and fluidity. This is not to say that you can't ever become comfortable if you never run even close to eight miles. But if you are doing that much and more but are still feeling like a fish out of water while running, stick with it! Eventually you will gain that feeling of running being your friend!  

 Odd Tidbit #2

This one is going to be most useful for those of you who will be doing races that last over about three hours. It has to do with physiological resets that take place in training and racing about every three hours. Here is the experience. You are doing a long bike ride that is going to last perhaps five hours. Up to around three hours into the ride you feel basically steady and on top of things. Then around that time you can go through a period of 10-15 minutes (sometimes longer) where things just don't feel in sync in your body. Maybe your energy levels drop or it feels like you are struggling to maintain your focus. But then at 3:30 into the ride you are back into your groove and it more or less lasts through the remainder of the ride. Here's the tidbit. There is some kind of shift physiologically at that three-hours in point, like a physiological transition area, where your body is readjusting something. During the transition, just like when you go from bike to run, things can feel awkward until you make it through and get back in the rhythm and flow of things. Here's the message: train this transition if you are going to need it in the race. If you are doing an event that will take you more than three-hours to complete, then design some training sessions that are also longer than three-hours. This will train your body to make it through that rough patch quicker with less impact. It's just like when you practice bricks in your training (doing bike to run sessions back to back) you get into the run flow much quicker than if you don't practice this transition. If you are doing an Ironman, it can be extremely beneficial to practice the transition that happens at six-hours as well. You can gain the adaptation to handle this in a few ways. Go out and do a 6:30-7:00 hour ride. Or, split it up and do a 5:30 ride followed by a 60-minute run. Both will take you over the six-hour physiological transition that happens. Prior to 1989 I never did any workout that lasted more than six-hours. I never practiced that second three-hour transition. In the race I was fine in the first transition that took place at about three-hours into an Ironman, but I fell apart after the second one at six-hours just like clockwork. Finally in 1989 I did a number of workouts throughout the season that lasted over six-hours. That also happened to be the first year that I won in Kona and the first Ironman I did where I was strong after that second six-hour shift rather than struggling. I mentioned this tidbit during a Fit Soul, Fit Body seminar a few years ago that Terrie Schneider was attending. Terrie was a top triathlete in the 1980's and early 1990's who eventually transitioned over into a world-class multiday adventure racer competing in seven Eco-Challenge competitions (300-mile events nonstop in rugged unmarked terrain). She almost burst out of her chair when I talked about this shift. Terrie said that in the adventure races once you start to get depleted that about every three-hours you go through a short transition of 5-10 minutes where you can see things that aren't there or suddenly be totally disoriented and feel like you are somewhere other than where you really are. She said no one had ever talked about those transitions before but they were very real and she had experienced them personally in her adventure races! The one question I get about this odd tidbit is what should someone do who is going to take twelve or fifteen or close to seventeen-hours to complete their Ironman. Do they have to train nine-hours or twelve-hours in a session to be able to handle the shifts that take place there? It appears that the answer is no. If you do training that takes you through those first two shifts (at three-hours and six-hours) that seems to be enough to prepare you for any others you will encounter if you will finish in a time that takes you through other shifts. So there you go! Two odd tidbits that likely no one has talked to you about before. I hope they help! Mark

item.title: What’s Important?
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: Last night I saw something that inspired me. It was not what you ordinarily think of as inspiration like a great race or a story of someone overcoming one of life’s insurmountable obstacles. It was a posting by a friend whose father passed away unexpectedly. She recounted amazing stories of their time together and of the depth and breadth he brought to everything he did throughout his life. It inspired me to sit with the preciousness and temporary nature of our time on this planet. These are two things that can get lost in all the dealings of the modern world. I stopped, to be grateful for all the days I've had so far and all the people who have been a part of making my time here so full. It also got me to reflect on a very personal loss. It was the life of my middle brother who passed away almost exactly a year ago. He was 54. He had Downs Syndrome. His name was David. Our lives, from the same parents, were very different. He won no Ironman titles. He never read the words on a page or carried on a meaningless conversation with friends. But he captured the essence of life. He smiled. He gave you a hug when he was happy. He expressed his feelings in his own way when he was not. Nothing was held back. I’ve had my struggles, my own depths of despair when I thought I would never make it to the other side and have life ease up just a bit. I’ve also had deeply gratifying experiences where I’ve seen how blessed I really am. But reading about the passing of a friend’s father, reflecting on the death of my brother begged me to look at life through a different lens. It showed me how transient life really is. Even as I age, even when I know it’s all going to have a closing curtain, there are still ways I view the world where I don’t really embody that reality. How can you be disappointed about anything if you are given one more day to live? How can the outcome of a huge effort be anything other than great if trying is seen as the true gift, not the outcome itself? Even with our limits, acknowledging how short life is helps us appreciate our journey all that much more. David is gone. My friend’s father is too. Their memories will last a long time, and I am sure both of them are cheering all of us on to live as full a life as we can.

item.title: Speedwork Tips
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
A lot of you are getting close to the time of the season when tempo sessions and speed workouts are going to be incorporated into your training. This usually brings up images of just going as fast as you can on each interval. But is it that simple? Not really! When it comes to anaerobic training there are a lot of nuances about how to optimize those sessions that rarely get talked about. Here are two key areas to keep in mind as you approach each of those sessions in your training.

Overall Pacing

Let’s take a look at one of the speed sessions that was the hallmark of my running workouts. The main set was simple: 8x400 with a half lap jog between each 400. It’s short. It’s not complicated, but the overall pacing is critical. I would divide the session into four segments, each one being two 400’s in length. As I went from one set of 2x400 to the next I would try to increase my speed. So the first 2x400 were the slowest of the eight and the last two were the fastest, with those last two being a close to an all out effort as I could go muster on the day. This is a simple track session, but the concept can be implemented every speed workout even if the intervals are of varying duration. So for example, maybe you are doing a ladder like 3x400, 2x800, 1xI600, 2x800, 3x400. You will likely be faster per lap on the first 400’s and 800’s than you are on the 1600. But the goal is to have the relative speed for each distance be a stronger effort. Then of course, the second set of 800’s and 400’s should be faster than the first ones. If you do your interval sessions like this, where you get progressively faster as you go through the workout, it will build into your body the capacity to also get faster as you move through your races. They will go from the experience of going fast initially but then just trying to hang on toward the end to ones where you can indeed start out at a solid pace, but then continue to build on that pace as the race unfolds.

Your Recovery Between Intervals

This piece of a speed session is just as important in terms of achieving gains from your workout as the actual part where you go fast. In both cycling and running I suggest having your recovery between the fast pieces be moving recovery. This means easy jogging on the run and shifting into an easy gear and continuing to spin between the fast segments of the workout on the bike. The real gold lies in how you do the recovery segments. But to help you understand those strategies, let’s remember why you are doing speedwork in the first place. Speedwork elevates your heart rate, eventually getting close to your max heart rate on the days when you are fresh enough to really push your effort. That heart rate level will be highest in running, slightly lower in cycling and a bit below than that in swimming. This has to do with the differences in how much body weight you have to sustain in each of those three sports. The closer you get to your max heart rate, the more you raise a marker called your VO2max. That is a measure of the amount of oxygen you can get into your system at any one time. The more you can get in, the faster you can go at any output level, even at the aerobic fat burning speeds that most people go during an Ironman. Spending training time getting closer and closer to your max heart rate is what will give you big gains in that element of fitness, and one of the reasons why speedwork is important for any distance triathlon that you are targeting. But there is another part of speedwork that is important to develop that has to do with improving your capacity to recover even at high output levels. For example, you are going really hard up a hill in a race and then you crest the hill, you want to be able to recover fast so that you can also cycle or run down the other side and then continue on fast on the flats that are to follow with lots of speed rather than have that same hill be the end of your top level efforts. That is where the recovery in your speed sessions comes in. Here is how to optimize your recovery between intervals to optimize both of those elements. If you give yourself a lot of recovery between each interval you will be able to hit a very high heart rate on each interval. That raises VO2max values, the first of the two goals of a speed session. But if your recovery jog or spin is actually fairly fast, you teach your body how to recover from a hard effort by only needing to back off just slightly from that effort before you relaunch again with another fast burst. Here are examples of both. In that same track workout I mentioned above of 8x400, if your goal is to get close to your max heart rate, then a half lap jog, even if easy, may not be enough to allow you the recovery you need to give a super high end effort. So what you may need to do is to run the first 6x400’s with your normal easy half lap jog recovery, but then for the final two 400’s take a full lap jog very easy to let your heart rate drop even further, which will afford you the ability to then reach a near max level for each of the final two 400’s. For me this was a key workout where the difference in times between those first two 400’s and the final two could be as much as 15-30 seconds, which is a huge amount for something that short. The opposite of that is going to be a workout where instead of allowing your recovery to get longer, you actually start to tighten the screws on your recovery and make that effort come closer and closer to the speed you will be going during your intervals. Here’s a classic example. Let’s say your main set running is going to be 3x1 mile of straights and curves. This workout is a continuous session that is actually three miles where you run the straight sections of the track fast, then jog the curve sections as your recovery. So the actual fast parts will be 1.5 miles in total and the recovery sections will also be 1.5 miles. However, to teach your body to recovery at a fairly fast pace (which is the real world of racing) here is how you will want to work the curve sections. Try to make each mile progressively faster by a significant amount by not only running the straights faster but also by running the recovery curves faster! So the first mile you jog the curves at a normal pace that lets your heart rate drop down enough enabling you to be ready to run fast again when you hit the straight section. Then during the second mile (again this is a nonstop workout) you jog the curves much faster so that when you get to the straights you know that you have recovered some but are not exactly happy to have to go fast again! Then in that third mile, the “recovery” on the curves is actually more a feeling of floating at a pace that is almost as fast as you went on the fast sections but just enough slower so that you know that you are not going at full speed. When I did this workout the difference in time between the first mile and the third could be as much as a minute or more faster. If you employ both of these recovery strategies (not both in the same workout), you will develop the full spectrum of physiology that you need to have the race of your lifetime!

item.title: Q&A: Avoiding The Bonk
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: Question: I have done a few Ironman races over the past two years (four to be exact) and I have had the same experience of bonking in each one of them. The feeling seems to start when I’ve got about an hour left on the bike and then just gets worse as I go through the marathon. Some of the races I start to feel better after I go through the 'run then jog then walk' phase and have a chance to get in more calories. But even then I still can’t seem to nail it in terms of steady energy levels throughout the race. Any suggestions?   Answer: There are a few things that can give you the feeling of bonking. One is definitely from being low on calories. Here is some math to consider. You can burn up to about 700 cal/hour when going at race pace, but can only absorb roughly 350/hour. That puts a person at a calorie deficit over an Ironman especially when you talk about carbohydrate calories. Keep in mind that even if you are racing aerobically and getting a lot of your calories from fat for fuel, that fat still needs carbohydrate present to initiate breaking it down for energy. And if you are going at high-energy outputs, the bulk of your calories are going to come from carbs. You only start the race with about 2,000 calories stored as glycogen in the first place though. Once those are gone, if you have not replaced them steadily throughout the event you will end up, yes, walking simply because there is no ready source of stored fuel to go fast, and even though your body will certainly have lots of fat still stashed away, without carbohydrate it cannot easily break it down for energy. Thus the bonk. The solution for this is to first and foremost regulate your pace so that you stay steady and keep the energy equation shifted toward fat burning to help spare stored glycogen. Next look at your source of carbohydrate in your energy drink that you are taking in on the course. Likely its main source for carbohydrate is maltodextrin. This form of carbohydrate can have a pass through rate of up to about 50% meaning that about 50% of what you take in never gets broken down and absorbed into your body. It just passes through the digestive system untouched and never gets to the working muscle. The solution here is to seek out a sports drink that has glucose in it as one of the sources of your carb. Glucose (or dextrose as it is often called in food) gets absorbed passively and is basically 100% absorbed because it doesn't have to breakdown before going into the blood. The ideal seems to be drinks or gels that have a mix of both maltodextrin and glucose (dextrose). The two seem to work to enhance absorption better than either as a single source. A second reason you can feel like you are bonking is from being low on sodium. When your sodium gets depleted you can have that same sensation of wanting to go faster but not being able to coordinate your muscles, your mind can be wandering and you feel low energy. The solution to this is to take sodium on the racecourse. I suggest a sodium tablet that you can actually taste the sodium if you suck on it in your mouth. This helps you to regulate very accurately how much you need. Let the tablet dissolve in your mouth until you reach the point where you body says “enough”. Any that is left you can spit out. A general rule of thumb to start experimenting with sodium during your training is to take in about 350mg/hour. This total should take into consideration the amount that is already in your sports drink. A third reason you can feel like you are bonking is from being low on magnesium. This is a mineral that like sodium is necessary for going fast. However, unlike sodium that can be basically replaced on the spot, magnesium only gets stored up over time with good diet or even supplementation. Foods high in magnesium include vegetables, beans and nuts. Stock up on those foods on a daily basis in your meals. Regardless of who you are, in an Ironman there is going to be some drop off in output over the course of the day. The key is to try to pace the early stages of the race conservatively so that you push that point into the latest stages of the race as possible. Ideally hold back enough in the first three quarters of the Ironman so that the drop off in pace is negligible in that final and critical last quarter of the event. I hope that helps, Mark

item.title: 100 Runs in 100 Days: Is it Smart?
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
There’s a running challenge that involves doing 100 runs in 100 days. It sounds impressive, and for sure if you could survive it unscathed your running would likely stand up to a new level. And best of all your logbook would be fat and happy with that unbroken string of entries in the running column. But if you’re real goal is to become a better runner, is this going to be the secret? Probably not! Consistency is essential for taking your running to a higher plain. But if your body is not ready for that much running, the consistency part will fall apart with a plague of common injuries– Achilles and IT band tendonitis, knee pain, hip pain, stress fractures to name a few. Who cares if you get to run #98 if the 99th pushes you past the point of no return and you spent the next 100 days limping through a handful of frustratingly slow jogs trying to run through the pain of an overuse injury? Instead of a run challenge that could spell disaster why not put one together that is nearly certain to bring success?

Baseline

Since consistency of running over a long period of time is a big part of becoming a faster runner, the first step is to know what your realistic baseline run level is. Step one is to determine the length of the bread and butter runs you are absolutely certain you could do day in and day out for weeks on end. It’s not the length of your longest weekly run, but rather the length of an average run you could do today, tomorrow, and every other day you train after that without any risk of injury. This is the average run that you would put on the table taking into account your current fitness and running history that you know is repeatable every day that you run each week in your training (again, exclusive of a long weekly run). Is it three miles? Is it forty minutes? Whatever that number is, it is perfect as long it’s realistic! The second important piece to know about your baseline is the length of run you are certain you could do for a long run on a weekly basis for the next 4-6 weeks, again without any risk of it causing injury or burnout. Whether the number is fifty minutes or an hour and fifty, it's the right number as long as it is realistic! The final question is the number of days per week that you can safely run. When coming up with this number, it should reflect the numbers of days on a moderate running week that are manageable (not the number of days you might run at the peak of your season getting ready for say an Ironman). If you are a heavier athlete or one who has had very little running background, this number will be less than a lighter triathlete or someone who has years of running base. Got that number? Now you are ready to make sense of it all and combine these three elements together in a plan that will make you a better runner! Let’s say you are able to run six miles on any given run day, complete a long weekly run of ninety minutes and can safely run four days per week (roughly every other day). The goal in consistency improvement is to increase each of these three elements over time so that you are able to run more on a daily basis, go longer in your long runs and increase the number of days each week that you can safely run. One of the best ways to increase these three key components of running is to work in reverse order. In other words, start by adding in more running days per week, then increase your long run length, and then finally increase your average daily run. And here is how.

Add in more days.

This begins by taking your moderate daily run and adding in one or two additional days in the coming week with a run that is half the length of that run. So if you can run six miles comfortably on your bread and butter run days, add in a fifth run that is about three miles. Then the next week take it out. The week following add it back in for two weeks, then take it out the week after that. If you can do that and feel like you are adapted, it’s time to work on building your longest run.

Increase your long run.

On the week that you take that extra run out after adapting to having it added, up your long run by about 15%. So if your long run is currently 1:30, then make your next one about 1:45. The following week do the same, adding in about an additional 10-15% onto your previous long run making it about two hours. In the third week cut the long run back by about 10-15% but add back in that extra short run. The following week, keep the short run plus add an additional 15% back onto your long run. The one after that up the long run by another 10-15%. Now you have added both a run day plus begun to build your long run.

Increase the length of your bread and butter runs.

Once you get to a long run length that is fairly consistent with what you will need to be ready for your goal races (say a 70.3 event), hold that level and shift your focus to working with some of the other moderate runs that you do within the week. Let’s say you want to plateau your long run at two hours, and you are able to do that along with the added shorter run day. The final step is to increase some of your daily consistent runs (the other three runs each week in this example). Start with the one that is the farthest from your long run (not one that is immediately following or one that is just prior to a long run) and work with increasing the length of it. In week one, build it to be about 50% longer than what is has been. So in this example, in week one make it a nine-mile run instead of six. The week following make is about 75-100% longer than the original length. In our example up it to be about 10-12 miles. Then in the third week, cut it back to 50% of the previous increased length. You can continue to build until that middle run is about equal to 50-75% of the length of the week’s long run. Once you are comfortable with that, you can add a final touch to your run consistency by gradually building the length of your shorter added run another 50-75% along with building a second one of your weekly bread and butter runs another 30-50%. Use the same strategy of building for two weeks then backing things off for one will allow for the adaptive recovery necessary to have your body rebuild with true responsive running fitness. Here are a few keys to making your consistency increases lead you to success. First, make sure that your overall weekly training volume increase does not exceed 10% from the previous week. Second, build in recovery. The body is not a linear machine that can handle increased training demand week after week on a steady basis. A better way is to push things up for a week or two, then back the total volume down in the third week to give enhanced recovery. Finally, increase consistency and volume in only one of the three elements each week. Read on to understand why! I started running in 1982. I went from ground zero to trying to do long runs of two hours or more and hitting the roads and trails almost daily. It took very little time to develop enough minor aches and pains in my joints and tendons to create total inconsistency in my running. The mistakes were clear. First I never assessed what a baseline bread and butter run would be. So instead of 2-3 miles, which was realistic, I immediately tried to run 4-7 miles in my daily runs. Instead of starting with a reasonable number of run days per week based on being a “no base” runner (I came from a swimming background and had tendons and ligaments that had no adaptation to weight bearing impact sports), right away I was trying to go out at least five days a week for runs. And my long run, well, instead of starting with a realistic 40-60 minute baseline in that first year I jumped within a few months to two hours or more. And I was trying to add all the elements in at the same time. I tried to build the length of my long runs, my moderate runs, and the total days per week that I ran all at once. Body explosion is the best way to describe the result! After two years of this nonsense it became clear that adaptation to running takes time. I backed it all down using the baseline assessments that I outlined earlier. Gradually over the course of about a year, starting at a realistic baseline running levels rather than what others who had been in the sport for years were doing, I was able to gain absorbable increases in long run length, add in additional days of shorter runs that built overall running consistency, and was able to increase the bread and butter run my body was able to handle from about three miles to close to eight. The real proof of the benefits came in the races where my run, which was my weakest sport at the beginning, became my strongest weapon!

This article originally appeared in the August, 2012 issue of Lava Magazine.

item.title: Q&A: Belief
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
From Amy:

I saw that you posted the "Belief" article that had originally been published in the Dec/14 Lava magazine (see article here). I thought I would share with you how much that article has meant to me. During 2014 I was training for my first IRONMAN and I felt very nervous. I was worried about the swim, and I spent the entire year working with a coach to improve my swim. My swim coach assured me before my race that my swim was great, and she was not worried about making that swim cut off. I reread this article all the time, and in particular one particular passage: "It's knowing in every cell of your body that you are willing to lock in, engage and commit regardless of how clearly you see your dreams or how out of reach they may appear in the toughest part of the journey. Real belief will take that risk anyway because you grasp how stupendous it is to give it your all, and that even if you come up short, your life will be better for having tried". I specifically reread it the night before my race, having my brother fetch the magazine the day before the race for me as I had forgotten it at home. The next morning, I missed the swim cut-off. I was maybe 100 yards, 2 minutes away. I heard the announcer call the swim, and I stood up and walked to shore - humiliated, ashamed, and so disappointed in myself. I went home, and the next morning I went on a 10 mile run, and that passage was stuck in my head. And during that run I started to work through my disappointment and decided that yes, my life was better for trying to reach my dream. And that I had more belief than ever that I could make it to that finish line. A month later I did a 14:49:28 ironman. Not the time I was hoping for, and I was probably over trained and tired. But I did it, and your written words helped me tremendously. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

Hi Amy

Your words and your story are touching! Thank you so much for sharing them with me. And first, congratulations on doing what is perhaps the toughest thing to do in sports, and that is to come back and relaunch after a bitter disappointment. But as you saw, that is usually what is required and the only way to fulfill those big dreams we have. That story has some history that I’ll share with you. The day after the awards in Kona that year I was flying back home. I was in the airport waiting for my flight. The editor from LAVA Magazine came up to me there and asked if I’d write something about the race. I said I’d be happy to and asked him what he was interested in. He just said that I know that race like no one else so just write about whatever I wanted to. I thought, geez! What the heck am I going to write about. He gave me full rein to write something that no one else could come up with. I had no idea what I would say. I fretted about it the entire flight home. I sat down in front of my computer a few different times with the Word doc open and nothing was coming, not one word. Then finally it came. I typed the word "Belief”. That was it. The piece just came like a river. Glad you liked it! Mark

item.title: Meet MAC Elite Athlete Sue deJesús
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: I started training with Mark Allen in November of 2015 after I had several months before read a book called 80/20 that describes the more aerobic philosophy of training that elite runners tend to follow. The extensive scientific research in the book convinced me this was the way for me to train—essentially 80% aerobic work, 20% moderate to high intensity work sprinkled in at certain phases of training. I found Mark’s coaching site surfing on the net and started communicating via email and he was immediately responsive to my questions about his methods. I was so surprised that a coach of his caliber, responsibilities and credentials was so responsive to me that I thought at first I must be interacting with an assistant that was answering my questions using Mark’s name, and it’s not really him. I don’t know how he does it, but it really was Mark Allen answering my questions. I felt Mark Allen’s training conformed perfectly to my shift in training philosophy, and his prices would actually save me training fees over the year so I switched coaches, started training with the method that matched my convictions and applied for a spot on Mark’s 2016 Elite Team. I was thrilled to be accepted for his 2016 Elite Team. When I ask Mark a question, he answers with such depth of experience and includes aspects and considerations that I hadn’t even considered when asking the question. He takes the time to explain and teach. He teaches me how to think when I’m not sure what to do, and teaches principles that look at the long term and the whole. I also appreciate the fact that Mark Allen’s methods make room for and strategically uses strength training with weights, a vital element especially for the older athlete! His way combines strength and aerobic training in a way where they don’t rob from each other, but complement each other. It’s the first time in my training that I have not had to abandon strength training at some point because of its negative impact on my aerobic training. One of the effects of this way of training is that I’m enjoying my workouts much more, and I’m more relaxed about adjusting workouts when my recovery or level of interest indicates, even not feeling bad about skipping a workout on occasion! This way of training prepares me better for the harder workouts when they do come and makes them more do-able. When my motivation might be lagging, or I’m tired, I now have an arsenal of approaches that he’s taught me that help me modify and still feel good about doing something. 2016 marks a new racing age group (F65-69), my return to a focus on the 70.3 Half Ironman distance, new coaching with Mark Allen and a restored body. Prior to this year, my race splits indicated that I was performing under my potential. I went to the doctor and tests showed my blood work was not normal and my heart valves were leaking. I believe these were the cumulative effects of using primarily high intensity training methods. Through herbs, homeopathy, supplements, prayer, a change in training methods with Coach Mark Allen, my health has been restored. My first race of the season brought me a win in Puerto Rico with my time even beating the age group below me and would have placed me 3rd in the men’s category M65-69. Of the eight half ironman races I’ve done, this one felt the best. I felt great for almost the entire race, and ended strong. Whereas I would never purchase any of the photos from my run portion in other races because I looked so tired and beat, this race pictures a happy Sue on the run course! I know these results are because of my new training and renewed health. I really look forward to what the rest of the year will bring as I race 70.3 Chattanooga and 70.3 Augusta. When things get tough, I tell myself, quoting my husband, who is himself a world champion bodybuilder, “Champions do daily what ordinary people do occasionally.” I see myself as an elite athlete and I do my best to model my lifestyle to that of a champion. A champion thinks differently than others and so a champion conducts him/herself differently, and they reap the results that all this brings. We all make choices and have attitudes that directly affect the quality of our life. Being physically fit provides me a means to enjoy life more fully. I encourage others to find the activity that best suits them, and learn to love what the required discipline brings. I believe that the sport of triathlon found me, and I chose it. It laid down the gauntlet and I picked it up. It has become a refining tool carving out levels of maturity through its unique disciplines and has made me a wiser, more efficient and compassionate person. Its fire has honed and pulled out the dross of personal doubts and made me challenge and overcome fears. It continually transforms my personal identity, changing how I see myself as I reach for higher and loftier goals. I believe that training and racing are a part of my personal destiny. Triathlons are my means of maintaining my good health. Races provide extra motivation on the occasion I need it to get out there when I might not feel like it, and they are a way to explore different parts of the country and world I’ve never seen before besides meeting some of the nicest people. I know I inspire those who are younger when they see me race. I’ve been asked many times by those many years younger as they pass me and see my age on my calf, “Are you REALLY 64???” “I thought that HAD to be a mistake! You look GREAT!” And I’ve been told “I want to be like you as I get older!” and my favorite from a 27 year old woman, “I’m 27 and dying (on this hilly course) and you’re doing so great, you’re my hero!” My goals this year are to race in three 70.3 races with my best self, seeing how much I can improve with my new training methods and see how high I can rank in my new age group! In 2017 if all continues to go well, I hope to qualify for and attend the 70.3 world championships in Chattanooga, TN. In 2018 I’m planning on doing my first full ironman!! The 140.6 full ironman is the only distance I have not done so I want to experience it. Just deciding which one to do will be my first challenge! Beyond 2018, having done all the distances, I will know what comes next and what my focus will be.   Back story: I now work in Pulmonary Rehabilitation at CJW Medical Center – Chippenham (Richmond, VA) where I have the opportunity to put everything together that I have learned. I assess, monitor and exercise and advocate for a special population of people who have many different lung diseases and conditions who come into the program because they are challenged with shortness of breath with exertion. The multiple benefits of aerobic exercise and weight training bring them greater endurance, stamina and strength for their activities of daily living, significantly improving their quality of life. These people become near and dear to my heart because I get to see them come in weak, unsteady in their gait, discouraged and many times home-bound, then after several weeks of training I have the personal fulfillment of witnessing what improved fitness and strength brings. Their lives are significantly changed for the better. By maximizing what their body can do they are more stable, hopeful, more independent, and their bodies now give them the power to be more active. They become my friends, I love them, and their courage constantly inspires me and brings me a perspective about life that causes me to be grateful for the activities that I can still do.  During my races I think about them, my sweetest cheering committee, and I’m motivated to do my best.   This picture is me playing my flute in a concert at the famous Alice Tully Hall in New York City with a youth choir, accompanied by flute, cello and piano. I’ve been playing flute since I was 13 years old. I sat first chair in the band for my whole school experience. I have a Master’s degree in flute performance and play with a harpist and guitarist for weddings, parties and dinners, freelancing in the Richmond, Virginia and surrounding areas. Making music is a creative process that brings beauty and satisfaction to my soul! Since it’s a universal language, it communicates and stirs all the emotions and conveys a unique beauty to all who listen and appreciate it regardless of nationality or culture. This is Carlos, my husband, who goes with me to every race: Canada, Puerto Rico, Idaho, New Orleans, Wisconsin, New York and many more! He’s my driver in pre-driving the bike course so I can refine my race strategy for the course, and he’s my chef on the road and home. When his cookbook is completed, it will be called “Only If It Tastes Good!” which is his philosophy about eating nutritious and good-for-you food. He doesn’t make a bad dish, ever! This guy loves to cook and experiment with flavors! I grew up in St. Paul Minnesota with an older brother and a younger brother and sister. They all still live there. I am the second oldest and by some twist of fate my parents managed to have a boy, a girl, a boy, and then my younger sister brought up the rear with the coveted place of youngest. I snow skied and ice skated, took a few swim lessons at the local YWCA, road my single gear bike all around, and ran hurdles and jumps made out of sticks in the ravine behind our family home. There were many more athletic than I in my gym classes, and I was never the first one picked for sports teams. My focus growing up was playing and practicing my flute, getting good grades, and being a tom-boy. Having an older and younger brother made me learn how to hold my own. I thought everyone played trucks in the dirt with their brother. On one occasion I sent a neighbor boy home crying after I slugged him. I still don’t remember what he said that made me do that! In college I majored in music performance and completed my Master’s Degree and then taught flute students at the University of Northern Colorado in Greeley, Colorado, the University of Iowa in Iowa City, Iowa and at the University of Richmond in Richmond, Virginia. After college I took up weight training with free weights and did a little running, enough to race a local 5k or 10k from time-to-time. I also went back to school for an associate’s degree in Respiratory Therapy (RT). Establishing a flute studio in a new town is not the easiest thing to do so being an RT allowed me to get a good job anywhere in the country. And then I got a Professional Nutrition Specialist Certificate just because I was interested in understanding nutrition better, and then a Master’s in Biblical Studies, just because I wanted to know my Bible better. Then I became a Certified Asthma Educator because I wanted to empower this population so they can feel better and take charge of their life. After my home was almost broken into, I realized I didn’t have the first idea about how to defend myself. To remedy this I studied Jiu Jitsu, Mui Thai kick boxing, and Krav Maga for a season and I traveled 4 hours round trip to Washington, DC and back for a total of 16 weeks to train in a special program that uses real life scenarios and fully padded “assailants” so we could practice self-defense skills with full striking impact. I finally felt confident about being able to protect myself, and better equipped to defend myself should I ever need to. I’m a firm believer in doing my part to prepare myself for life’s challenges. If my skills or knowledge are found wanting, then I’ll do something about it, if it’s in my power to do it. My start in Triathlons Something happened to me in 2001, the year I was going to turn 50 in August. I was taking care of patients in the hospital I worked in and began to reflect on the aspects of disease, pain and discomfort that are life-style related and for the most part, preventable. I thought about getting older and how I wanted my elder years to be: I didn’t want to hobble around and not be able to enjoy my life, or be limited in what I could do. And most of all, I didn’t want to be responsible for my own demise! I made a decision right then and there to get into the best shape of my life and stay there. Through a series of seemingly serendipitous connections, I was asked to speak on nutrition for a newly formed women’s athletic endeavor called Triathlon Moms created by Kim Kredich, the wife of the then, University of Richmond’s women’s swim coach. Triathlon Moms was established for the purpose of helping women, especially moms, become physically active by training for and completing sprint triathlons. The newly formed groups’ first Sprint was only six weeks away. I sponsored a woman, and then began to want to be a part. Already crazy busy, I wondered where these thoughts were coming from, but I felt drawn to participate. After talking with Kim I decided to go to a few practices and see how things went. I had swimming lessons as a child, so I knew the basics and was comfortable in the water. As a grade schooler I had a one speed bike that I rode around the neighborhood, but had never ridden a bike with more gears. To start I bought a Cannondale mid-priced road bike that I could easily sell if I hated triathlons. On my first ride I dropped my chain and had to figure out how to put it back on all by myself, and fell over the first time I tried my clip in pedals! After a few practices I decided to stay in the program. I’m still in contact with several ladies from this special group. Crossing the finish line at this mid-July hot Sprint was the closest to death that I had ever felt in my life. Where’s the oxygen? Surely there’s a tent that provides this. I’m going to die! I’m sure of it! All these thoughts raced around my head as I gasped at the finish line trying to recover my breath and calm the heaving of my chest. Pacing? Whatever plan I had went out the window in the heat of the moment! I back-stroked when I got tired with freestyle on the swim, I had a death grip on the handles of my bike as I navigated scary hills and turns, and I thought the run course was never going to end. Miraculously and unbelievably, I came in third in my age-group. A few weeks later I was musing to myself, “you know, with more training, and greater effort maybe I could win my age-group!” I was bit by the triathlon bug and I liked the challenge! I continued to train with Triathlon Moms for a few years and completed other Sprints, none as life-threatening as my first though. I did one or two races during the season and continued to place mostly 2nd or 3rd with an occasional 1st. I hired my first triathlon coach in 2008 and began to make steady and significant improvements. I didn’t have the nerve to try an Olympic distance until 2011. I won first place in my age group at my first Olympic race on a very cold and rainy day, a day I almost didn’t show up for due to the weather. The water was in the low 60’s and only with my coach’s encouragement did I stay to race. I’m so glad I did! That year I raced in 2 olympic and 3 sprint races and came in 1st in all but one. That one was my first time at Age Group Nationals, and I came in 7th. Funny how winning can become great encouragement to continue! In 2012 I was USAT’s National AquaBike Champion F60-64, with All American status. #1 in the nation felt super sweet and an incredible reward for a lot of hard work. I also came in 3rd at USAT’s Age Group National Championship, receiving their All American honorable mention for the year. 2013 was the year I tried the half IRONMAN distance and qualified for the 70.3 world championships my first time out. We flew to Henderson Nevada and I came in 10th in my age group. I was 1st out of the water and 5th off the bike. I ended the year 5th in the world for my age group and was awarded WTC’s All World Athlete Silver status. I also won first place at the USAT AquaBike 70.3 National Championship race. 2014 I again qualified for the 70.3 world championships and raced in beautiful, hilly Mt. Tremblant in Canada, and ended up at year end ranking second in the world for F60-64 and getting WTC’s All World Athlete Gold status! I also raced USAT’s Age Group National Championship, coming in 6th, and received their All American designation. Though I have qualified for USAT Age Group World Championships many years, the only race I was able to accept was the 2015 World Championship race in Chicago, Illinois. It was great to be on Team USA! I experienced the thrill of competing for my country. The swell of patriotism I felt was a surprise to me and what fun to gather with my compatriots from all across the nation! I have a feeling that racing triathlons and training will be a part of my life for a long time to come, for as long as I am still able, still motivated, and still having fun.

item.title: The Move That Almost Cost Me Victory
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
This was a defining moment in my career. It was an instant in time that in retrospect was as significant as any in my career. It was a split second in Ironman history that only Pauli Kiuru, the photographer who shot it or me will ever know about. It almost cost me my fifth Hawaiian Ironman World Championship, but the lesson learned was absolutely critical in having a key element in my knowledge base that allowed me to win my sixth!
The year was 1993. I was trying to win my fifth Ironman World Championship in five starts. The string started, as you likely know, in 1989 defeating Dave Scott in an epic battle. It continued with wins in 1990 against Scott Tinley by the largest margin of any win I had there. Then it went to 1991 when I battled eventual Ironman Champ Greg Welch. We ran side by side off the bike, but I was able to pull away before exiting town and going onto the Queen K Hwy. 1992 saw an even tougher challenger in Cristian Bustos of Chile. We ran virtually neck and neck through the half marathon point. Fortunately that was where I was able to make a move that stuck.
1993 was not like any of these previous years. Four titles had come with head-to-head battles or races where I was unchallenged in the lead. This year Pauli Kiuru of Finland put a gap on me early in the marathon that grew to over seven-minutes. It was the first time that I was going to have to close a gap on the eventual second place finisher. It was a dynamic that I had no template to follow that would tell me I was on track to fulfill my dream.
My legs were not cooperating early in the marathon. They felt heavy, like two bloated logs. The signs when analyzed later told that I was at critically low levels of magnesium. Without enough magnesium in my body, every effort would feel labored. And unlike sodium that can be remedied on the spot, magnesium is a mineral essential for peak athletic performance that can only be replaced over painfully long periods of time. Race day is not a long period of time if measured by the scale of magnesium!
The first 10k through town on the marathon was like that dream where you want to be going fast but it’s like you are running through thick syrup. But this was no dream. It was the reality of how I felt. Kiuru came off the bike just ahead of me, but he was out of sight and pulling away in no time. 7:30 measured the gap at the largest between us. He was tough. The Fins have a word “Sisu” that cannot be translated directly into English. But a loose interpretation of it means that when you embody it, you are willing to go to death to fulfill your mission. Pauli was on that kind of mission!
I had reigned in about three-minutes of his massive lead by the time I entered the Energy Lab with about ten-miles to go in the marathon. This was my chance! The Energy Lab was my home, my solace, my opportunity. The first part of it is a long downhill into a direct headwind. That is nice in the heat of Kona! But it is not reality. The remaining part to the farthest point of the Energy Lab had a side wind that had a slight head component to it, which again cools things beyond the reality of what you would face at the turn around.
I knew this was the time. I took those four miles as a four-mile race rather than only four miles in the scope of a marathon. I had to come out of the Lab in the lead if I was to win. That was a tall order. There were still over four-minutes separating Pauli and me. But again, this was my territory!
I went for it. The downhill would gain me no time, but I knew that. The flat to the turnaround would give me back a bit. But the guts of my strategy would happen in the next two miles. Once you make the turn and have to retrace your steps out of the Energy Lab the wind is now more at your back than in your face. Body temps rise dramatically. Heart rates sore. If you go by the numbers, you have to slow down.
But I was like the Kalahari tribesman on the hunt. Body temp was secondary to the goal, the kill, the pass in the race. I could feel my core temperature rise, but it was not yet critical. I was closing on Pauli. He was following his heart rate. The numbers were not looking good in his mind! He slowed. He was thinking insurance for the final 10k once he exited the Lab. I knew the race had to be won in there, immediately!
The gap closed at astronomically impossible speeds. We both knew there was the very long, lonely uphill to navigate to get out of the Energy Lab. That is an uphill with a straight tailwind. That is the most brutal segment of the Ironman marathon. There is no way no matter how slow you run to keep your core temperature from skyrocketing. Even if you walked you would be questioning what you were doing in there!
I was trying to win an Ironman World Championship. That quest does not care about your core temperature. I knew that if things went well I could go at full force out of the Lab before my core thermometer hit the switch point between heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Does that sound insane? Of course if you are sitting in your chair. But out on the Ironman race course the goal outweighs sanity!
I was able to close the gap on Pauli just before we made the left turn to head up that treacherous race-defining hill that exits the Energy Lab and drops you back out on the Queen K Hwy where the winds will shift just enough to the side to bring your body temperature back down to a survivable level. And that was where this photo was taken.
Why was it so critical? Why did it almost cost me the race? Here is the reason. I had been in Pauli’s situation many times in my early years racing the Ironman in Hawaii. I knew it well. You are leading the race. You are pulling away from everyone including the favorite. But then things switch. Suddenly you are not in command. Someone is turning the tables on you and your lead is eroding. Then there is a moment when you realize there is nothing you can do. You are helpless. All the training for years that got you that lead is not what will get you to the top of the podium on that one iconic day in Kona.
You will be passed. It’s just a matter of time, and when it happens you will have to come up with a reason to keep giving everything you have even after your biggest dream as a triathlete gets ripped out of your hands. It’s a moment that is the depth of depths. I had been in Pauli’s position six times before I was able to be the one who was victorious. I knew what he would face in the moment when I pulled away and relinquished his finish to second place at best.
I respected Pauli as an athlete and as a person. When I caught him, I touched his back as an acknowledgement of the great race he was having. I touched his back to acknowledge how immense it was for me to close the gap he had opened. I touched his back to acknowledge that I knew what he would now have to deal with as I passed him. But in that moment of compassion that touch gave Pauli an energy that he was missing!
He gained energy from that touch. He sped up. I thought to myself that it was the stupidest thing I had ever done as a competitor! Pauli stuck with me for what seemed like an eternity. I have no idea what the real world of time was that we ran side by side. But it was more than I had ever anticipated. I made a vow in those eternal moments that in the future, should I make a pass on a fellow competitor, regardless of how great a friend they were or how much I respected their accomplishments as an athlete, that competition was just that: do everything you can to bring out the best in your own race.
I was indeed eventually able to pull away from Pauli just before we made the left turn to head up the most demanding chunk of the Ironman course. I crested the hill and turned right onto the Queen K Hwy in the lead. My core temperature was well beyond what anyone would have said was safe or sustainable or within the realm of what anyone could have and still be running at world-record speeds.
I set a course record on that day, my third in five starts. I won my fifth Ironman World Championship with a come-from-behind victory. The lesson learned about that one-second touch of acknowledgement would be something that I would need two years later when I ran past more than one athlete who I felt great camaraderie with but who I also wanted to beat on my way to a sixth title in Hawaii!

item.title: The Move That Almost Cost Me Victory At The Ironman
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
