That was a tall order. There were still over four-minutes separating Pauli and me. But again, this was my territory! I went for it. The downhill would gain me no time, but I knew that. The flat to the turnaround would give me back a bit. But the guts of my strategy would happen in the next two miles. Once you make the turn and have to retrace your steps out of the Energy Lab the wind is now more at your back than in your face. Body temps rise dramatically. Heart rates sore. If you go by the numbers, you have to slow down. But I was like the Kalahari tribesman on the hunt. Body temp was secondary to the goal, the kill, the pass in the race. I could feel my core temperature rise, but it was not yet critical. I was closing on Pauli. He was following his heart rate. The numbers were not looking good in his mind! He slowed. He was thinking insurance for the final 10k once he exited the Lab. I knew the race had to be won in there, immediately! The gap closed at astronomically impossible speeds. We both knew there was the very long, lonely uphill to navigate to get out of the Energy Lab. That is an uphill with a straight tailwind. That is the most brutal segment of the Ironman marathon. There is no way no matter how slow you run to keep your core temperature from skyrocketing. Even if you walked you would be questioning what you were doing in there! I was trying to win an Ironman World Championship. That quest does not care about your core temperature. I knew that if things went well I could go at full force out of the Lab before my core thermometer hit the switch point between heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Does that sound insane? Of course if you are sitting in your chair. But out on the Ironman race course the goal outweighs sanity! I was able to close the gap on Pauli just before we made the left turn to head up that treacherous race-defining hill that exits the Energy Lab and drops you back out on the Queen K Hwy where the winds will shift just enough to the side to bring your body temperature back down to a survivable level. And that was where this photo was taken. Why was it so critical? Why did it almost cost me the race? Here is the reason. I had been in Pauli’s situation many times in my early years racing the Ironman in Hawaii. I knew it well. You are leading the race. You are pulling away from everyone including the favorite. But then things switch. Suddenly you are not in command. Someone is turning the tables on you and your lead is eroding. Then there is a moment when you realize there is nothing you can do. You are helpless. All the training for years that got you that lead is not what will get you to the top of the podium on that one iconic day in Kona. You will be passed. It’s just a matter of time, and when it happens you will have to come up with a reason to keep giving everything you have even after your biggest dream as a triathlete gets ripped out of your hands. It’s a moment that is the depth of depths. I had been in Pauli’s position six times before I was able to be the one who was victorious. I knew what he would face in the moment when I pulled away and relinquished his finish to second place at best. I respected Pauli as an athlete and as a person. When I caught him, I touched his back as an acknowledgement of the great race he was having. I touched his back to acknowledge how immense it was for me to close the gap he had opened. I touched his back to acknowledge that I knew what he would now have to deal with as I passed him. But in that moment of compassion that touch gave Pauli an energy that he was missing! He gained energy from that touch. He sped up. I thought to myself that it was the stupidest thing I had ever done as a competitor! Pauli stuck with me for what seemed like an eternity. I have no idea what the real world of time was that we ran side by side. But it was more than I had ever anticipated. I made a vow in those eternal moments that in the future, should I make a pass on a fellow competitor, regardless of how great a friend they were or how much I respected their accomplishments as an athlete, that competition was just that: do everything you can to bring out the best in your own race. I was indeed eventually able to pull away from Pauli just before we made the left turn to head up the most demanding chunk of the Ironman course. I crested the hill and turned right onto the Queen K Hwy in the lead. My core temperature was well beyond what anyone would have said was safe or sustainable or within the realm of what anyone could have and still be running at world-record speeds. I set a course record on that day, my third in five starts. I won my fifth Ironman World Championship with a come-from-behind victory. The lesson learned about that one-second touch of acknowledgement would be something that I would need two years later when I ran past more than one athlete who I felt great camaraderie with but who I also wanted to beat on my way to a sixth title in Hawaii!

item.title: Understanding ENVE's Wheel Development
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: Many of our customers were surprised when we discontinued the venerable SES 8.9. After all, it was our most aerodynamic wheel set and was responsible for countless PR bike splits. The truth is our wheel development is always evolving and the lessons learned from our previous wheels help us to refine future models. When it came time to redesign a Triathlon/Time Trial wheelset, we addressed three critical areas for improvement: aerodynamics, stability, and weight. Often it is a tradeoff, adjusting one element for another in an effort to create a great all-around wheel. Much like training, one mustn’t focus on just one area if you want to excel as a complete athlete. Taking a cue from other SES wheels, the dissimilar rim geometries optimized through wheel in frame development improves the efficiency of airflow offering superior aerodynamics versus the 8.9 with 25mm wide tires. Speaking of tires, road tubeless is ready for primetime and tire manufactures have made huge gains with regards to less rolling resistance, weight, and better ride quality. Naturally the 7.8 wheels are tubeless compatible. Tubular models are also still available for those looking for the lightest weight setup. When wind is a factor, choosing a wheelset shouldn’t have to be. Having the confidence to go fast and not get blown around is critical to a quick bike leg. Whether it’s at Kona or your local Tri, the stability of the 7.8 is closer to that of our 4.5 when dealing with crosswinds, keeping you fresher heading into your run. A boon for any rider especially smaller and lighter ones. Lastly, the ability to shed weight always helps performance. From out of the saddle accelerations to rolling and downright hilly courses, drastically reducing the weight of the 7.8 relative to the 8.9 can be felt with the first pedal strokes. Add to that the improved braking that comes for the new molded brake track and you end up with a wheelset that will lead to many more memorable races. Similar to racing, lessons can be learned from past experiences that hopefully lead to success in future endeavors. We are confident that what we have learned from past wheel developments have allowed us to build a truly no-compromise wheelset for racing and everyday training. To find out more, visit: http://enve.com/products/ses-7-8/.

item.title: The Best Six Seconds Of My Life
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: In 1989 at the Ironman World Championship in Hawaii I broke the course record going 8:09:14. It was the first time 8:10 had been broken in Kona. It was the first time 8:20 had been broken in Kona. It was the first time 8:25 had been broken in Kona! It was done against the man who held the course record going into the race, Dave Scott. It took the two of us having great days on the same day to make it happen. Over eight-hours of racing within a few feet of each other drove a spike into the heart of what had been the top level the world had seen and set a standard that likely few at the time thought was possible. The following two years saw no records fall. It takes decent weather for that to happen. It takes great racing as well. Maybe it wasn’t possible unless the pressure between challenger and eventual champion lasted until the closing miles of the marathon. Maybe on your own survival mechanisms trump any desire to keep drilling deep into your potential once a gap has opened up and the lead feels secure. The Ironman in 1992 was the kind of race that kept the pressure on. I was having a head to head battle with Cristian Bustos of Chile. We went through the half marathon side by side. But I had a sense miles earlier that once he started to slow I could put in a surge to open a gap and it would stick to the end. And that’s what I did. I surged. The rope of hope loosened from his grip and the gap opened, then grew. I went into the Energy Lab with a comfortable lead. I came out with one that was even bigger. That’s when I got some news that changed my focus. Someone yelled out, “If you can hold six-minute pace the last 10k you might break your record!” You have to understand that I had settled into a pace that I knew would get me to the finish in the lead without blowing up. Six-minute pace, if it was even possible, could put it all at risk. A second thing you must understand, that late in the race it’s totally impossible for my brain to be able to figure out a split from one mile marker to the next! Logically calculating anything was so far out of the realm of what I could do, but I thought I’d try! I picked it up. Three miles later, with three miles to go, people were yelling that I’d be close. “Gee thanks! How close? How fast am I running? How fast do I need to go to make SURE I’ll break it?” Unfortunately the info was not offering me the luxury of anything concrete. All I knew was that the battle with Bustos was over and now I was racing against a competitor with no heart, no care for how I was feeling. I was racing against an unseen challenger who I wouldn’t be able to see until I was within seconds of the finish, and if it was close I would have no idea until that very moment who might come out on top. It was a player who could not be intimidated or broken with a surge. It was simply the clock…tick-tock. “You’ve got to pick it up” was all I was getting from the sidelines. Oh yes, of course, no problem, let me just drop it down under six-minute pace to make sure I break the record! I made the turn onto Ali'i Drive. I was going to win. Bustos was well behind and the finish was close. It could have been a long glorious stretch of road to soak it all in, but I had begun my sprint. I was alone, but it looked like I was racing side by side with a phantom competitor for the win. I could finally see the clock. It was just about to turn 8:09:00. I had exactly 13-seconds left if I was going to break the record. But there still seemed to be a huge amount of turf between me and the tape that would end my Ironman day and I had no idea how much time it would take. This was not savoring. It was suffering. I looked like I was at the end of a track race not an Ironman. The gap to the finish closed, the clock ticked off more seconds. I covered more ground. More seconds were gone. The finish was close. More seconds disappeared. I crossed. The time: 8:09:08! I’d done it! I broke my previous record by a mere six-seconds! How could two Ironman races be so close? How could two races with such different dynamics end up with finish times almost identical? It was only the second time in Ironman history that the champion had gone under 8:10:00, but this time the drop in the course record was the smallest of margins. Those were the best six-seconds of my life!

item.title: When Things Don't Go Your Way
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: This was one of the most chilling looks back ever for me. I had run through the town of Kona along Ali’i Drive and was about to face the long uphill that led out onto the meat of the marathon. This was the pinnacle. It was 1987. It was my fifth trip to Kona to race the World Championships. Everyone else was following and unable to keep up. I’d trained massive volumes that year and it seemed to have paid off. The look back was not from concern but from a moment of pinching myself to make sure it was real. In 1987 there was no leader board. The only way you knew where your competitors were was if someone cheering had been keeping track and yelled out a split. This was an impossible bit of info to get if you were the first through any one spot on the course, though. Everyone behind would know the gap, but by leading it was just a guessing game. I had to rely on that primitive inner sensing ability that could tell where the field was and how each competitor was feeling. It was like the hunt in reverse. I sensed I had a huge gap. The look back confirmed it. There was no one in sight! I’d later learn that by mile-seven of the marathon I led the nearest competitor by four-minutes. That’s a very nice cushion to have, and I was continuing to pull away! But I still needed to have my internal GPS dialed into how my competitors were feeling. Let’s face it; no device is ever going to signal the moment someone is going to give up. It’s impossible to measure someone’s will and resolve to catch you. Those are the human pieces of competition that can help you rise above all challenges, or if you can sense someone’s collapse coming exploit the weakness of your toughest rival. The look back was like a shot of adrenalin. No one came into my sights, not even Dave Scott, who as usual in the late 1980’s was the odds on favorite going into the race. I felt solid. Thousands were cheering along the route through town and I was trying to draw in as much of their excitement as I could. That year the marathon started at the very southern end of Ali’i Drive and ran roughly 10km straight north through the entire town of Kona. Just parallel to the finish you took a right turn up Palani Road, the hill that is still the first real measure of continued strength or unraveling weakness on the run. At the top of the hill you take a welcomed left turn that says you made the climb up and out of town. It’s also the first moment of reality where Ironman reveals its vicious teeth. Twenty-miles of running lay ahead and no one is out there cheering. It’s you and the lava. It’s you and the heat. It’s you and your sweat-soaked feet that will at some point get blistered if they haven’t already. I climbed the Palani Road hill feeling like a champ. Huge gaps are tough to make up, especially when you are out of sight. Second place would likely not even be at the bottom of the hill by the time I made my way out onto the lava. With every step I took away from Palani Road the sound of the crowd cheering got softer. I made the left turn. The crowd was gone. The lava was ahead. It was hot beyond belief. The cheers through town had masked a critical mistake I was making. I had not taken in enough calories in those first six miles to sustain the pace I was going. The climb up Palani Road nearly sucked the tank dry. I tried desperately to make up for lost time fueling. I guzzled as much as I could get in at each aid station. But it was like a cork being able to plug a huge crack in a dam. With the first step of those final twenty-miles of the Ironman marathon every primitive instinct delivered the same message: I was nearly out of gas and at some point I would be walking, and there was nothing I could do about it. From high to low in a matter of steps, I could also feel the strength of those charging from behind. They were pacing. I’d been racing. They were patient. I’d wanted to wrap the whole thing up before I left town. Everyone else was waiting for those eternally tough miles outside of town before they unleashed their best. Their strategy would work. Mine would not. I was no longer in the race. I was in a battle against myself. Sheer will kept me looking like I was still charging. At mile-sixteen of the marathon I had actually put another minute in the man who was in second place, Dave Scott. But two miles later physiology trumped mental will and I was forced to take my first steps walking. Five-minutes may as well have been five-seconds. I would have needed a thirty-minute lead to be able to shuffle through those final eight miles and win. Should I just give up and quit or should I continue? What was my purpose now? It would only be a matter of time before Scott and likely others would pass me. What was the day’s goal going to transform into now? Victory was out of the question. The heat of Hawaii’s sun forced these kinds of discussions with myself! What’s the reason to go on? Why continue? The main goal I’d come into the race with was not even in the realm of possibility. I could quit. I could try, but for what? Walking is not running, and walking for someone who had led the biggest race in the sport for miles is humbling. Primitive took hold again. Knowing something without knowing why it’s important is part of our ancient genetics. It calls us to take action that we know is essential to take without logic giving us a reason why we should take it. Only through time will we be able to look back and understand why. Did all the animals that were mortal enemies climbed the same canyons before Indonesia’s devastating tsunami in 2004 knowing why there were called up and away from the ocean? I dialed into that same sense. The purpose became clear and it was simple: give one hundred-percent of what I had to give, even if it meant walking at a capacity that was twenty-percent of my potential on another day. And that’s what I did. I walked as fast as I could until I found the energy to jog. Then I’d run until the fumes dried up and I had to walk once again. Give one hundred-percent even in this twenty-percent situation. The effort would end up being enough to finish in second place. Dave Scott was the champion that day. It became his last Ironman victory. It was the last Ironman that I was forced to walk during the marathon. In the medical tent after the race it was discovered that I was bleeding internally. I was severely dehydrated. My body was shutting down. I was rushed to the hospital. Clearly this was not how I had envisioned the day panning out. But the impact of what I went through to get to the finish that day was something that ran deep and would come into play in the future. It taught me a lesson that propped up my efforts through the difficult moments that are always part of Ironman day in every race I would come back and have there. The lesson kept me engaged fully in my winning years at the Ironman in the down moments when I was only working at eighty-percent. I still gave one hundred-percent because of what I learned in 1987. Had my DNA missed being branded through that tough experience, it’s very likely I would have given far less in those critical moments rather than staying engaged fully and completely. No one wins every race they enter or sets a PR every time out of the blocks. But that doesn’t mean the effort was a loss! I tell my coaching clients that the only bad race is one where you don’t learn something from it. This nugget was a critical piece for me to learn, and one that enabled me to pull off six World Championship victories in Kona!

item.title: Ironman Race Day Nutrition
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been receiving a lot of questions about fueling during an Ironman recently. Many have been from clients whose Ironman nutrition plan fail part way through the race. It is indeed a tough part of a long day on the course to dial in. Let me outline some basics on this for you.

Calorie Amount

The starting point is to figure out the number of calories per hour you are going to try to target. Too many calories or too few and the result is going to be the same: you will slow down. Too few means you will run out of gas. Too many calories causes the stomach to back up and revolt. That is because your stomach is working in slow motion during an Ironman and if you dump more calories into it than it can break down and absorb, it will cause everything to just sit there rather than get the fuel to the working muscle. In general a good target is to try to get in 300-350 cal/hour. Much more than that and backup can happen along with bloating and that uncomfortable nauseous feeling. Much less than that, and you run the risk of working on fumes and being forced to slow way down. The best way to try to dial in what amount is right for you is to track how many calories you take in during your long rides. The right amount will enable you to maintain your pace throughout the entire workout and allow you to get off the bike feeling like you could run without having to eat a huge meal.

Calorie Source

Once you have an idea the number of calories you will need per hour, the next piece is getting them from the right source. Five hundred calories from peanut butter is going to absorb very differently than five hundred calories from a sports drink! During the race your stomach is not going to be getting the same blood flow sent to it that it has when you are sitting still. Its functions are slowed way down, including its ability to break down complex forms of calories. What this means in terms of an Ironman is that it is best to try to get your calories from sources that require very little work to break down and be absorbed. Sports drinks are usually the best for this as they are designed to work when your body is under exercise pressure. Solid foods are at the opposite end of this spectrum and can take far longer to break down and get absorbed. To find out what works for you, again test options during your long rides. If you are barely able to tolerate the taste of a drink in training, it will definitely not work in a race! The taste must be something that is really good during your rides for it to have a chance on race day.

Taste Variety

Most people are able to find a source of calories that tastes good and is in a very basic carbohydrate form so that it absorbs quickly. The one catch with this is that an Ironman will require many hours of sipping on the same drink to get the calories you need. To help with this requirement, try to find at least two tastes options that work for you. Having the ability to switch up the flavor and even consistency in what you are taking in will help you to be able to tolerate your calories much longer than if you have one and only one drink with one flavor.

Total Fluid Intake

Next up is making sure you are not exceeding your body’s ability to absorb fluids. In general the maximum absorption rate for most people is about 30-40oz (1-1.5 liters) per hour. More than that and things just sit there and slosh around. Again see what amount per hour works for you during your long rides. Then for the race, make sure to factor in both your sports drink volume plus any additional water you will be drinking. This gets a bit more tricky when you are carrying all your own calories and not relying on any from aid stations. If this is going to be you, you will likely concentrate your sports drink into just a few bottles and are going to have to dilute it with sips from water bottles that you get from aid stations. Some preplanning on how much of each to target no more than the total intake that is recommended will help in keeping the volume in check that gets to your stomach.

Make Room

One of the rarely talked about pieces of race day absorption is getting your whole digestive system ready and open for business. That means making sure there is not a lot of stuff already in it. And that can be accomplished by cutting out as much fiber as you can during the final few days before a race. Fiber in the digestive track can be a huge factor in causing the race day backup and nauseous feeling that a lot of people get. This is often a problem for triathletes who generally eat quite healthfully and dine on foods with a lot of fiber in them. It can even be from the fiber in their foods race morning. Maybe oatmeal is your favorite race morning food, but the fiber in it will slow things down later and can be the cause of stomach bloating and upset. I’ve had a number of clients who always had race day stomach issues that were able to solve the problem by eliminating almost all fiber in those final couple of days prior to the race. There you go! Let me know if you try these strategies and if they help you to conquer the nutritional piece in your next Ironman. ~ Mark Allen

item.title: A Shout Out To Race Directors, Especially Dave McGillivary
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: I wanted to send a shout out to the collective group we all know as race directors, and to one in particular. Without race directors none of us would have running races or cycling events or triathlons to take part in. And without the races probably many of us would have never picked up those sports and would be living a lifestyle that is very different than the one of health and fitness that the community of athletes getting ready for races fosters. So thank you race directors around the world! Now to the one that I want to bring to the forefront for a moment, and I know he doesn’t like to be at the forefront in this way. It’s Dave McGillivray of DMSE Sports who is the race director for the Boston Marathon. On April 15, 2013 he had to deal with a situation that probably no one ever imagined would happen at such a great celebration of athletics. Yes, I’m talking about the terrorist attack near the finish line at Boylston Street. It was life altering and shook everyone, especially the worldwide community of athletes. In a matter of 12-seconds two bombs exploded within a few hundred yards of each other in what many could easily say was the most heinous attack on a public sporting event in history. It was a situation that fortunately no other race director has had to deal with even though the ramifications are still rippling far and deep. Security has tightened at every single big public race. We are no longer allowed to enter certain areas without the right security credentials. It’s a stark reminder that no one anywhere is off limits for the ill intended. It brought deep sadness and rage to the victims and their loved ones. It stunned the athletic community. It was an act that is at the complete opposite end of the human experience and the celebration that happens from running a marathon. An endurance event is like creating the United Nations of Sports. A marathon doesn’t discriminate against you because of you are a man or a woman, old or young. A marathon doesn’t see the color of your skin or the size of your body. It is just there begging anyone who wishes to come and cover 26.2 miles at the pace that is right for them. An Ironman doesn’t favor one over another because of spiritual preference or sexual orientation. It just presents all who come the chance to cover 140.6 miles in less than seventeen-hours. Endurance events brings us together as equals and allows us to celebrate our common thread of pursuing an athletic dream instead of highlighting our differences in ideologies. We stand on the start line united, nervous, humbled about what we are about to undertake. We all speak the same language when it’s over, the language of athletic experiences, which as many will attest can also be life altering. Dave McGillivary and his crew picked up the pieces and have staged the Boston Marathon every year since 2013, never for a moment letting the horrendous memories of April 15th be anything less than an essential reason to keep the race alive in memory of those who died. So support all the race directors out there. They are doing their part to create the United Nations of Sport. And by racing instead of dividing us because of our differences we help create a model for bringing people together in honor of our commonalities.

item.title: IRONMAN World Championship 2016
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded: The race is iconic. The day is like no other. The IRONMAN World Championship in Hawaii sets the standard for every endurance event on the planet. Here is a brief look back at this amazing day and incredible experience that starts even before the race begins. Enjoy!

item.title: MarkAllenCoaching Elite Team Application 2017
item.dc:creator: Mark Allen
item.content:encoded:
MarkAllenCoaching is accepting appolications for its 2017 Elite Age Group Team. Here are some details and how to apply. The team will be comprised of up to twenty athletes. Each team member will receive among other things a team racing kit, a significant discount off a year of coaching with Mark and specials throughout the upcoming season from our partners who I feel are the best product in each of their respective categories. If you are interested in applying to be a member of the Elite Age Group Team here is the specific information to send back to us at support@markallencoaching.com:
  • Name 
  • Gender 
  • Race Division for 2017 
  • Address
  • Tell us why you would like to join the MarkAllenCoaching Elite Team.
  • Are you currently coached by anyone? 
  • Your 2016 triathlon results including: 
-Race name and date -Race distance -Division  -Division place  -Overall place  -Finishing time and splits for each part of the race if you have them  -Preliminary 2017 race schedule -A high resolution action photo of you either training or racing and a headshot that may be used on our website and marketing materials -Your Facebook, Twitter and/or Instagram addresses. Applications will be accepted through December 12, 2016 and those selected for the team will be contacted during the week of December 19th, 2016. I look forward to your applications and to those who will be part of our team for the upcoming 2017 season! Mark
